item.title: CondaConda
item.description:
conda config --add channels [url] Copy
Ê∏ÖÂçéÊ∫ê conda config --add channels https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/anaconda/pkgs/free/ conda config --add channels https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/anaconda/pkgs/main/ conda config --add channels https://mirrors.tuna.tsinghua.edu.cn/anaconda/cloud//pytorch/ conda config --set show_channel_urls yes Copy

conda create -n [EnvName] python=[Version] Copy
Example conda create -n TEST python=3.8 Copy

conda activate [EnvName] Copy

conda deactivate Copy

conda env list Copy

conda env remove -n [EnvName] Copy


conda install jupyter Copy

# ÂàõÂª∫Êï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÁéØÂ¢É conda create -n data_analysis python=3.9 # ÊøÄÊ¥ªÁéØÂ¢É conda activate data_analysis # ÂÆâË£ÖÂ∏∏Áî®ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÂ∫ì conda install numpy pandas matplotlib seaborn scikit-learn jupyter # ÂÆâË£ÖÂÖ∂‰ªñÊúâÁî®ÁöÑÊï∞ÊçÆÂàÜÊûêÂ∑•ÂÖ∑ conda install -c conda-forge jupyterlab ipython statsmodels Copy

# ÂàõÂª∫Ê∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†ÁéØÂ¢É conda create -n deep_learning python=3.9 # ÊøÄÊ¥ªÁéØÂ¢É conda activate deep_learning # ÂÆâË£Ö TensorFlow conda install tensorflow # ÂÆâË£Ö PyTorch conda install pytorch torchvision torchaudio cpuonly -c pytorch # ÂÆâË£ÖÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ∏∏Áî®ÁöÑÊ∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†Â∫ì conda install -c conda-forge keras matplotlib pandas scikit-learn jupyter Copy

# ÂàõÂª∫ËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ËßÜËßâÁéØÂ¢É conda create -n computer_vision python=3.9 # ÊøÄÊ¥ªÁéØÂ¢É conda activate computer_vision # ÂÆâË£Ö OpenCV conda install -c conda-forge opencv # ÂÆâË£ÖÂÖ∂‰ªñÂ∏∏Áî®ÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ËßÜËßâÂ∫ì conda install numpy matplotlib scikit-learn jupyter # ÂÆâË£ÖÊ∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†Â∫ìÔºàÁî®‰∫éËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ËßÜËßâ‰ªªÂä°Ôºâ conda install tensorflow pytorch torchvision torchaudio cpuonly -c pytorch # ÂÆâË£ÖÂõæÂÉèÂ§ÑÁêÜÂ∫ì conda install scikit-image pillow Copy

# ÂàõÂª∫ NLP ÁéØÂ¢É conda create -n nlp python=3.9 # ÊøÄÊ¥ªÁéØÂ¢É conda activate nlp # ÂÆâË£ÖÂ∏∏Áî®ÁöÑ NLP Â∫ì conda install -c conda-forge spacy nltk gensim # ÂÆâË£ÖÊ∑±Â∫¶Â≠¶‰π†Â∫ì conda install snownlp tensorflow pytorch torchvision torchaudio cpuonly -c pytorch # ÂÆâË£ÖÂÖ∂‰ªñÊúâÁî®ÁöÑÂ∫ì conda install pandas scikit-learn matplotlib # ÂÆâË£Ö transformers Â∫ìÔºàÁî®‰∫éÈ¢ÑËÆ≠ÁªÉÊ®°ÂûãÔºâ pip install transformers # ÂÆâË£Ö jupyter Âíå jupyterlab conda install -c conda-forge jupyter jupyterlab # ‰∏ãËΩΩÂíåÂÆâË£Ö spaCy ËØ≠Ë®ÄÊ®°ÂûãÔºà‰æãÂ¶Ç en_core_web_smÔºâ python -m spacy download en_core_web_sm Copy

item.title: Union-FindUnion-Find[1]
item.description:
Áî®‰∫éËß£ÂÜ≥ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂàÜÁªÑÈóÆÈ¢ò
ËÅîÈÄöÈóÆÈ¢ò
Êìç‰Ωú
ÂêàÂπ∂ (Union)
Êü•ËØ¢ (Find)


ÂàùÂßãÂåñÊó∂ÊØè‰∏™ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂêÑÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈõÜÂêà
fa[i] Âç≥ÊåáÂêë ---„Äâi ÊâÄÂú®ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
int fa[MAXN]; void init(int n){ for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) fa[i] = i; } Copy


ÊØè‰∏™ÈõÜÂêàÂè™ËÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
ÊïÖÊü•ËØ¢Êó∂ÂõûÊ∫ØËá≥ÊâæÂà∞‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊòØÂÅúÊ≠¢
find(x) Â∫îÂÆö‰πâ‰∏∫xÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑÊâÄÂú®ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
int find(int x){ if(fa[x] == x) return x; else return find(fa[x]); } Copy


ÂêàÂπ∂ÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÈÄªËæëÊòØÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÂèòÊàêÂè¶‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
ÂàÜËß£Êìç‰Ωú
find(i) iÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊâÄÂú®ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
fa[i] Âç≥ÊåáÂêë ---„ÄâÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
find(j) jÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊâÄÂú®ÈõÜÂêà‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
ÊâæÂà∞iÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊâÄÂú®ÈõÜÂêàÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥† ‰ΩøËØ•ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†ÊåáÂêë jÂÖÉÁ¥†ÁöÑ‰ª£Ë°®ÂÖÉÁ¥†
void merge(int i, int j){ fa[find(i)] = find(j); } Copy


‰ª§ÊâÄÊúâËäÇÁÇπÈÉΩÊåáÂêëÂêå‰∏Ä‰∏™Áà∂ËäÇÁÇπ
int find(int x){ if(x == fa[x]) return x; else{ fa[x] = find(fa[x]); //Áà∂ËäÇÁÇπËÆæ‰∏∫Ê†πËäÇÁÇπ return fa[x]; //ËøîÂõûÁà∂ËäÇÁÇπ } } int find(int x){ return x == fa[x] ? x : (fa[x] = find(fa[x])); } Copy


ÂàùÂßãÂåñ
void init(int n){ for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i){ fa[i] = i; rank[i] = 1; } } Copy

ÂêàÂπ∂
void merge(int i, int j){ int x = find(i), y = find(j); // * ÂÖàÊâæÂà∞‰∏§‰∏™Ê†πËäÇÁÇπ if (rank[x] <= rank[y]) fa[x] = y; else fa[y] = x; if (rank[x] == rank[y] && x != y) rank[y]++; // * Â¶ÇÊûúÊ∑±Â∫¶Áõ∏Âêå‰∏îÊ†πËäÇÁÇπ‰∏çÂêåÔºåÂàôÊñ∞ÁöÑÊ†πËäÇÁÇπÁöÑÊ∑±Â∫¶+1 } Copy

class Ufds { private: vector<int> parents; vector<int> ranks; public: Ufds(int n) { parents.resize(n); ranks.resize(n); for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) { parents[i] = i; ranks[i] = i; } } int findSet(int a) { if (parents[a] != a) { parents[a] = findSet(parents[a]); } return parents[a]; } void unionSets(int a, int b) { a = findSet(a); b = findSet(b); if (a == b) return; if (ranks[a] < ranks[b]) { int temp = a; a = b; b = temp; } parents[b] = a; ranks[a]++; } }; Copy

#include <cstdio> #define MAXN 5005 int fa[MAXN], rank[MAXN]; inline void init(int n) { for (int i = 1; i <= n; ++i) { fa[i] = i; rank[i] = 1; } } int find(int x) { return x == fa[x] ? x : (fa[x] = find(fa[x])); } inline void merge(int i, int j) { int x = find(i), y = find(j); if (rank[x] <= rank[y]) fa[x] = y; else fa[y] = x; if (rank[x] == rank[y] && x != y) rank[y]++; } int main() { int n, m, p, x, y; scanf("%d%d%d", &n, &m, &p); init(n); for (int i = 0; i < m; ++i) { scanf("%d%d", &x, &y); merge(x, y); } for (int i = 0; i < p; ++i) { scanf("%d%d", &x, &y); printf("%s\n", find(x) == find(y) ? "Yes" : "No"); } return 0; } ## Â©¥ÂÑøÁöÑÂêçÂ≠ó Copy

ËæìÂÖ•Ôºönames = ["John(15)","Jon(12)","Chris(13)","Kris(4)","Christopher(19)"], synonyms = ["(Jon,John)","(John,Johnny)","(Chris,Kris)","(Chris,Christopher)"] ËæìÂá∫Ôºö["John(27)","Chris(36)"] Copy

class Solution { private: unordered_map<string, string> parent; unordered_map<string, int> frequency; string find(string x) { if (parent.find(x) == parent.end()) return x; if (parent[x] != x) parent[x] = find(parent[x]); return parent[x]; } void merge(string i, string j) { string x = find(i); string y = find(j); if (x==y) return; if (x < y) { parent[y] = x; frequency[x] += frequency[y]; frequency[y] = 0; } else{ parent[x]=y; frequency[y]+=frequency[x]; frequency[x]=0; } } public: vector<string> trulyMostPopular(vector<string>& names, vector<string>& synonyms) { // Parse and initialize frequencies for (const string& name : names) { int pos = name.find('('); string nameStr = name.substr(0, pos); int freq = stoi(name.substr(pos + 1, name.size() - pos - 2)); parent[nameStr] = nameStr; frequency[nameStr] = freq; } // Process synonyms for (const string& synonym : synonyms) { int pos = synonym.find(','); string name1 = synonym.substr(1, pos - 1); string name2 = synonym.substr(pos + 1, synonym.size() - pos - 2); merge(name1, name2); } // Build the result vector<string> result; for (auto& entry : frequency) { string name = entry.first; int freq = entry.second; if (name == find(name)) { string nameFreq = name + "(" + to_string(freq) + ")"; result.push_back(nameFreq); } } return result; } }; Copy

public static void sort(int nums[]){ Bubble(nums, nums.length-1); } //* ‰ºòÂåñ ÊØèÊ¨°Âæ™ÁéØÁöÑÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÊ¨°‰∫§Êç¢Âêé ËØ•‰∏ãÊ†áÂæÄÂè≥ÈÉΩ‰∏ç‰ºöÂÜçÂèëÁîü‰∫§Êç¢ */ public static void Bubble(int nums[],int j){ if(j==0) return ; int x=0; for(int i=0;i<j;i++){ if(nums[i]>nums[i+1]) { int temp=nums[i]; nums[i]=nums[i+1]; nums[i+1]=temp; x=i; } } Bubble(nums, x); } Copy

public static void insertionSort(int A[]){ Insertion(A, 1); } public static void insertionSort(int A[],int p){ if(p==A.length) return; int key=A[p]; int i=p-1; while(i>=0 && key<A[i]){ A[i+1]=A[i]; i--; } A[i+1]=key; Insertion(A, p+1); } Copy

Use the first element as a pivot

if the input is random, ok
if the input is presorted (or in reverse order)
all the elements go into S2 (or S1)
this happens consistently throughout the recursive calls
Results in behavior

Choose the pivot randomly

generally safe
random number generation can be expensive

Use the median of the array ‰∏≠‰ΩçÊï∞
The median is the middle element if the array is sorted.

Partitioning always cuts the array into roughly half
An optimal quicksort: O(N log N)
However, it is expensive to find the exact median
e.g., sort an array to pick the value in the middle

We will use the median of three
Compare just three elements: the left-most, right-most, and center
Swap these elements if necessary so that

A[left] = Smallest
A[right] = Largest
A[center] = Median of three
Pick A[center] as the pivot
Swap A[center] and A[right ‚Äì 1] so that the pivot is at second-last position


Assumptions
Pivot Selection: Median of 3
Base Case: Array size <= 10
Running time
Divide
Pivot selection: O(1)
Partitioning: O(n)
Recursive calls: T(i) + T(n-i-1)
Conquer and Combine: O(1)


Worst-Case
The pivot is the smallest element, all the time
Partition is always unbalanced


Best-Case
Partition is perfectly balanced
Pivot is always in the middle (median of the array)









Average-Case



The inner loop consists of an increment/decrement (by 1, which is fast), a test, and , a jump.
There is no extra juggling as in mergesort.


The priority queue is a data structure that allows at least two operations

insert
delete in/deleteMax
finds, returns, and removes the minimum elements in the priority queue

Heaps are ‚Äúalmost perfect binary trees‚Äù

All levels are full except possibly the lowest level
If the lowest level is not full, then nodes must be packed to the left

Given a binary heap of node number n and height h

n is within
The height
The structure is so regular, it can be represented in an array and no links are necessary !!!
Insert in time
Locate the current minimum in time
Delete the current minimum in time

item.description:
Def: Graph A graph is a pair of
V is the collection of vertices
E is the collection of edges
Def: Directed Graph (u, v) and (v, u) are distinct for some edges (u, v) .
Def: Undirected Graph (u, v) and (v, u) are identical for all edges (u, v) .

Adjacency list Representation

is a linked list of all v that (u, v) .
,
In directed graphs, is the out degree of v
Adjacency matrix Representation

is a matrix such that if .

What does DFS do?
Traverse all vertices in graph, and thereby
Reveal properties of the graph. Four array s are used to keep information gathered during traversal.
Four Arrays
: the color of each vertex visited
white: undiscovered
gray : discovered but not finished processing
black: finished processing
: the predecessor pointer pointing back to the vertex from which u was discovered
: the discovery time
a counter indicating when vertex u is discovered
: the finishing time
a counter indicating when the processing of vertex ( and all its descendants ) is finished
Algorithm DFS(G) Input: Graph GGG Output: Vertex traversal of graph GGG for all vertex u‚ààV(G)u \in V(G)u‚ààV(G) do color[u]‚Üêwhitecolor[u] \gets \text{white}color[u]‚Üêwhite//Initialize pred[u]‚ÜêNULLpred[u] \gets \text{NULL}pred[u]‚ÜêNULL end for time‚Üê0time \gets 0time‚Üê0 for all vertex u‚ààV(G)u \in V(G)u‚ààV(G) do//Start a new tree if color[u]==whitecolor[u] == \text{white}color[u]==white then DFSVisit(uuu) end if end for Export to clipboard
Algorithm DFSVisit color[u]‚Üêgraycolor[u] \gets \text{gray}color[u]‚Üêgray//u is discovered d[u]‚Üê++d[u] \gets ++d[u]‚Üê++time//u's discovery time for all v‚ààadj[u]v \in \text{adj}[u]v‚ààadj[u] do//Visit undiscovered vertex if color[v]==whitecolor[v] == \text{white}color[v]==white then pred[v]‚Üêupred[v] \gets upred[v]‚Üêu DFSVisit(vvv) end if end for color[u]‚Üêblackcolor[u] \gets \text{black}color[u]‚Üêblack//u has finished f[u]‚Üê++f[u] \gets ++f[u]‚Üê++time//u finish time Export to clipboard
The output of DFS
The time stamp arrays: d[v], f[v]
The predecessor array: pred[v]
Def: DFS Forest Use to define a graph as follows:

It is a graph with no cycles, and a collection of trees.
HandShaking Theorem If G=(V, E) is an undirected graph
If G=(V, E) is an directed graph





DFS Properties
u is a descendant ( in DFS trees ) of v, if and only if is a subinterval of .
u is an ancestor of v, if and only if contains .
u is unrelated to v, if and only if and are disjoint intervals.

Proof The idea is to consider every case.
Assume wlog.
If , then
u is discovered when v is still not finished y et ( marked gray) u is a descendant of v ;
u is discovered later than v u should finish before v;
hence we have is a subinterval of .
If , then
Obviously and $[d[v] , f[v]] are disjoint;
Which means that when u or v is discovered, the others are not marked gray;
And hence neither vertex is a descendant of the other

Theorem An edge in an undirected graph is either a tree edge or a back edge.
Proof Assume . Then, v is be discovered while u is gray.
Hence v is in the DFS subtree rooted at u.
If , is a tree edge.
If , is a back edge.


Def: Articulation Let G=(V, E) be a connected undirected graph.
An articulation point (cut vertex) of G is a vertex whose removal disconnects G

Given a connected graph G, how to find all articulation points?
Brute Force Solution



Remove a vertex and its corresponding edges one by one one from G.
Test whether the resulting graph is still connected or not say by DFS.
The running time is O (n ‚àó(n + e)) .


The root of the DFS tree is an articulation point if it has two or more children.
A leaf of the DFS tree is not an articulation point.
And for other internal vertex v in the DFS tree, v is an articulation point if
if there is one subtree rooted at a child of v that does not have a back edge which climbs higher than v.

Def: Low and high Using the discovery time in the DFS tree to define low and high.
If there is a subtree rooted at a children of v which does not have a back edge connecting to a vertex with discovery time smaller than d[v] , then v is an articulation point.

Let Low (w) be the smallest value that a descendant of w can climb up by a back edge.
We use d[v] to express the ‚Äúhight‚Äù of v.
v is ‚Äúhigher‚Äù than u if v and u are on the same branch of the DFS tree and d[v] < d[u] .
If v and u are on different branches, d[v] and d[u] are not compatible by the time-stamp structure.

#include<iostream> using namespace std; const int N=30; bool used[N]; int way[N]; int n; int m; void dfs(int u,int cnt){ if(cnt==m){ for(int i=1;i<=m;i++){ cout<<way[i]<<" "; } puts(""); return ; } for(int i=1;i<=n;i++){ if(way[u-1]<i && !used[i]){ used[i]=true; way[u]=i; dfs(u+1,cnt+1); used[i]=false; } } } int main(){ cin>>n>>m; dfs(1,0); return 0; } Copy

Algorithm Maximum Contiguous Subarray Problem if i=ji = ji=j then return R[i]R[i]R[i] else s1‚ÜêMCS(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)s1 \gets \text{MCS}(R, i, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor)s1‚ÜêMCS(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)//Using floor function for lower rounding s2‚ÜêMCS(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j)s2 \gets \text{MCS}(R, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor + 1, j)s2‚ÜêMCS(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j) A‚ÜêMaxSuffix(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)+MaxPrefix(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j)A \gets \text{MaxSuffix}(R, i, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor) + \text{MaxPrefix}(R, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor + 1, j)A‚ÜêMaxSuffix(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)+MaxPrefix(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j) return MAX(s1,s2,A)\text{MAX}(s1, s2, A)MAX(s1,s2,A) end if Export to clipboard

Cpp Ëß£Ê≥ï
class Solution { public: int maxPreffix(vector<int>&nums,int i ,int j){ int ans=nums[i]; int tmp=0; for(;i<=j;i++){ tmp+=nums[i]; if(tmp>ans){ ans=tmp; } } return ans; } int maxSuffix(vector<int>&nums,int i ,int j){ int ans=nums[j]; int tmp=0; for(;i<=j;j--){ tmp+=nums[j]; if(tmp>ans){ ans=tmp; } } return ans; } int MSA(vector<int>&nums,int i ,int j){ if(i==j){ return nums[i]; } else{ int S1=MSA(nums,i,(i+j)/2); int S2=MSA(nums,(i+j)/2+1,j); int A = maxSuffix(nums,i,(i+j)/2)+maxPreffix(nums,(i+j)/2+1,j); return max({S1,S2,A}); } } int maxSubArray(vector<int>& nums) { return MSA(nums,0,nums.size()-1); } }; Copy

Algorithm Polynomial Multi1(A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)) if n=0n=0n=0 then return a0√ób0a_0 \times b_0a0‚Äã√ób0‚Äã else A0(x)=a0+a1x+‚ãØ+a‚åän2‚åã‚àí1x‚åän2‚åã‚àí1A_0(x) = a_0 + a_1x + \dots + a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor - 1}x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor -1}A0‚Äã(x)=a0‚Äã+a1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1‚Äãx‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1 A1(x)=a‚åän2‚åã+a‚åän2‚åã+1x+‚ãØ+anxn‚àí‚åän2‚åãA_1(x) = a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor +1}x + \dots + a_nx^{n-\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}A1‚Äã(x)=a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚Äã+a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+an‚Äãxn‚àí‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã B0(x)=b0+b1x+‚ãØ+b‚åän2‚åã‚àí1x‚åän2‚åã‚àí1B_0(x) = b_0 + b_1x + \dots + b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor - 1}x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor -1}B0‚Äã(x)=b0‚Äã+b1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1‚Äãx‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1 B1(x)=b‚åän2‚åã+b‚åän2‚åã+1x+‚ãØ+bnxn‚àí‚åän2‚åãB_1(x) = b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor +1}x + \dots + b_nx^{n-\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}B1‚Äã(x)=b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚Äã+b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+bn‚Äãxn‚àí‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã U(x)=PolyMult1(A0(x),B0(x))U(x) = \text{PolyMult1}(A_0(x), B_0(x))U(x)=PolyMult1(A0‚Äã(x),B0‚Äã(x)) V(x)=PolyMult1(A0(x),B1(x))V(x) = \text{PolyMult1}(A_0(x), B_1(x))V(x)=PolyMult1(A0‚Äã(x),B1‚Äã(x)) W(x)=PolyMult1(A1(x),B0(x))W(x) = \text{PolyMult1}(A_1(x), B_0(x))W(x)=PolyMult1(A1‚Äã(x),B0‚Äã(x)) Z(x)=PolyMult1(A1(x),B1(x))Z(x) = \text{PolyMult1}(A_1(x), B_1(x))Z(x)=PolyMult1(A1‚Äã(x),B1‚Äã(x)) return U(x)+(V(x)+W(x))x‚åän2‚åã+Z(x)x2‚åän2‚åãU(x) + (V(x) + W(x))x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + Z(x)x^{2\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}U(x)+(V(x)+W(x))x‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+Z(x)x2‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã end if Export to clipboard

Example By 2
Algorithm Polynomial Multi2(A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)A(x),B(x)) if n=0n=0n=0 then return a0√ób0a_0 \times b_0a0‚Äã√ób0‚Äã else A0(x)=a0+a1x+‚ãØ+a‚åän2‚åã‚àí1x‚åän2‚åã‚àí1A_0(x) = a_0 + a_1x + \dots + a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor - 1}x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor -1}A0‚Äã(x)=a0‚Äã+a1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1‚Äãx‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1 A1(x)=a‚åän2‚åã+a‚åän2‚åã+1x+‚ãØ+anxn‚àí‚åän2‚åãA_1(x) = a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + a_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor +1}x + \dots + a_nx^{n-\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}A1‚Äã(x)=a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚Äã+a‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+an‚Äãxn‚àí‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã B0(x)=b0+b1x+‚ãØ+b‚åän2‚åã‚àí1x‚åän2‚åã‚àí1B_0(x) = b_0 + b_1x + \dots + b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor - 1}x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor -1}B0‚Äã(x)=b0‚Äã+b1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1‚Äãx‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚àí1 B1(x)=b‚åän2‚åã+b‚åän2‚åã+1x+‚ãØ+bnxn‚àí‚åän2‚åãB_1(x) = b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + b_{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor +1}x + \dots + b_nx^{n-\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}B1‚Äã(x)=b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã‚Äã+b‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+1‚Äãx+‚ãØ+bn‚Äãxn‚àí‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã Y(x)=PolyMult2(A0(x)+A1(x),B0(x)+B1(x))Y(x) = \text{PolyMult2}(A_0(x)+A_1(x), B_0(x)+B_1(x))Y(x)=PolyMult2(A0‚Äã(x)+A1‚Äã(x),B0‚Äã(x)+B1‚Äã(x)) U(x)=PolyMult2(A0(x),B0(x))U(x) = \text{PolyMult2}(A_0(x), B_0(x))U(x)=PolyMult2(A0‚Äã(x),B0‚Äã(x)) Z(x)=PolyMult2(A1(x),B1(x))Z(x) = \text{PolyMult2}(A_1(x), B_1(x))Z(x)=PolyMult2(A1‚Äã(x),B1‚Äã(x)) return U(x)+(Y(x)‚àíU(x)‚àíZ(x))x‚åän2‚åã+Z(x)x2‚åän2‚åãU(x) + (Y(x) - U(x) - Z(x))x^{\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor} + Z(x)x^{2\lfloor \frac{n}{2} \rfloor}U(x)+(Y(x)‚àíU(x)‚àíZ(x))x‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã+Z(x)x2‚åä2n‚Äã‚åã end if Export to clipboard

item.title: DAA-Programming-AssignmentDAA-Programming-Assignment
item.description:
The Maximum Subarray Sum problem seeks to find the contiguous subarray (containing at least one number) which has the largest sum among all possible subarrays of a given integer array.

Define as the maximum sum of a subarray ending at index . The recurrence relation can be expressed as:

where is the value of the array at index .


: The input array containing integers.
: The maximum sum of a subarray ending at position in array .
: A function returning the maximum of its arguments.

The pseudocode for the Dynamic Programming solution of this problem is as follows:
Algorithm MCS function MCS(SSS) if SSS is empty then return 0 end if F[0]‚ÜêS[0]F[0] \gets S[0]F[0]‚ÜêS[0] maxSum‚ÜêS[0]maxSum \gets S[0]maxSum‚ÜêS[0] for i‚Üê1i \gets 1i‚Üê1 to length(S)‚àí1\text{length}(S) - 1length(S)‚àí1 do F[i]‚Üêmax‚Å°(F[i‚àí1]+S[i],S[i])F[i] \gets \max(F[i-1] + S[i], S[i])F[i]‚Üêmax(F[i‚àí1]+S[i],S[i]) if F[i]>maxSumF[i] > maxSumF[i]>maxSum then maxSum‚ÜêF[i]maxSum \gets F[i]maxSum‚ÜêF[i] end if end for return maxSummaxSummaxSum end function Export to clipboard


Initialization: The initialization of F[0] and maxSum takes constant time, .
Loop: The loop runs times if is the length of the array. Within each iteration, the operations (calculating and updating maxSum) take constant time.
Overall: The overall time complexity of the algorithm is , where is the number of elements in the input array, as each element is processed exactly once.


This documentation was written in a Markdown file.
In my code, it can output all optimal solutions, both on the screen and to an output file.
The number of integers in the input is unknown. You can input an array of arbitrary size.
Here's a refined version of the guideline section of your documentation:

The implementation was performed using standard C and compiled with the GCC compiler.


Directory Structure
To compile the code, ensure you are in the correct directory. If you are in the correct path, you could see the following file tree structure: . ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ Makefile ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ README.md ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ in ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ in_out ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib.c ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib.h ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ lib.o ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mcs ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ mcs.c ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ mcs.o Copy
Compile the Code:
Once you have confirmed the directory structure, simply type make in the terminal: make Copy This command will compile the source files and should produce the following output: gcc -c mcs.c gcc -c lib.c gcc mcs.o lib.o -o mcs Copy

After compiling the code, you can execute the program by entering the following command in the terminal:
./mcs <InputFilename> Copy
For example, to run the program with the input file named in, type:
./mcs in Copy
This command will run the program using the data specified in the in file. Make sure that the input file is in the correct format and location as expected by the program.

item.title: DAA-Assignment-2DAA-Assignment-2
item.description:
A tree  is the maximum spanning tree of a graph  if  is a spanning tree of  and the weight on the tree  is maximized.
Mr. Smart designs an algorithm to find the maximum spanning tree. Is his algorithm correct?
Algorithm MaxST(G, w) Require: a connected graph G=(V,E)G = (V, E)G=(V,E) with a weight function w:E‚ÜíZw: E \to \mathbb{Z}w:E‚ÜíZ Ensure: the maximum spanning tree TTT of GGG begin E‚Üêsort(E)E \gets \text{sort}(E)E‚Üêsort(E) in decreasing order based on www A‚Üê{}A \gets \{\}A‚Üê{} for all u‚ààVu \in Vu‚ààV do CREATE-SET(u)\text{CREATE-SET}(u)CREATE-SET(u) end for for all (u,v)‚ààE(u, v) \in E(u,v)‚ààE do if FIND-SET(u)‚â†FIND-SET(v)\text{FIND-SET}(u) \neq \text{FIND-SET}(v)FIND-SET(u)ÓÄ†‚Äã=FIND-SET(v) then add (u,v)(u, v)(u,v) to AAA UNION(u,v)\text{UNION}(u, v)UNION(u,v) end if end for return (V,A)(V, A)(V,A) end Export to clipboard
Note that his algorithm is exactly same as Kruskal‚Äôs algorithm except that the loop from line 7 to 12 iterates on edges in the decreasing order. (15pts)
I think his opinion is correct.


Heavy Edge: An edge is considered a heavy edge crossing a cut if its weight is the maximum among all edges crossing that cut.
Safe Edge: An edge is considered safe if its inclusion in the growing forest does not violate the properties of the maximum spanning tree (i.e., it does not create a cycle with edges already included in the MST and its addition results in a spanning tree with the maximum possible total weight).

Case I: Heavy Edge is Safe Edge

If the heavy edge is part of the MST, then by definition, it contributes to forming the maximum possible weight of the MST.
Since it is the heaviest edge across a particular cut and it is part of the MST, it is safe because its exclusion would result in a non-optimal tree (i.e., a tree with less total weight).
Case II: Heavy Edge is Not Safe Edge

Assume for contradiction that there is a heavy edge across a cut which is not included in the MST, implying it is not safe.
If is the heaviest edge crossing the cut and is not included, then to maintain connectivity and maximize total weight, there must be another edge through the cut.
However, was defined as the heaviest edge, so no edge can have a greater weight than.
This leads to a contradiction because it would imply that the current MST is not truly the maximum spanning tree as excluding reduces the possible total weight.

Given a weighted connect graph , a path from  to  is simple if no vertex on the path is repeated. A simple path is maximum if the length on the simple path is the largest. Such length is called maximum distance from to , denoted as .
Mr. Smart designs the following algorithm to find the maximum simple path from one vertices to all other vertices. Is his algorithm correct? Prove your answer.
Algorithm MaxSP(G, w, s) Require: a connected graph G=(V,E)G = (V,E)G=(V,E) with a weight function w:E‚ÜíZw: E \rightarrow \mathbb{Z}w:E‚ÜíZ, a source vertex s‚ààVs \in Vs‚ààV Ensure: the maximum distance Œî(s,v)\Delta(s,v)Œî(s,v) for all v‚ààVv \in Vv‚ààV begin for all u‚ààVu \in Vu‚ààV do d[u]‚Üê‚àûd[u] \gets \inftyd[u]‚Üê‚àû color[u]‚ÜêWcolor[u] \gets Wcolor[u]‚ÜêW end for d[s]‚Üê0d[s] \gets 0d[s]‚Üê0 pred[s]‚ÜêNULLpred[s] \gets \text{NULL}pred[s]‚ÜêNULL Q‚Üênew PriorityQueue(V)Q \gets \text{new PriorityQueue}(V)Q‚Üênew PriorityQueue(V) while QQQ is not empty do u‚ÜêQ.extractMax()u \gets Q.\text{extractMax}()u‚ÜêQ.extractMax() for all v‚ààadj[u]v \in \text{adj}[u]v‚ààadj[u] do if d[u]+w(u,v)>d[v]d[u] + w(u,v) > d[v]d[u]+w(u,v)>d[v] then d[v]‚Üêd[u]+w(u,v)d[v] \gets d[u] + w(u,v)d[v]‚Üêd[u]+w(u,v) Q.increaseKey(v,d[v])Q.\text{increaseKey}(v, d[v])Q.increaseKey(v,d[v]) pred[v]‚Üêupred[v] \gets upred[v]‚Üêu end if end for color[u]‚ÜêBcolor[u] \gets Bcolor[u]‚ÜêB end while return d[u]d[u]d[u] for each u‚ààVu \in Vu‚ààV end Export to clipboard
Note that his algorithm is exactly same as Dijkstra‚Äôs algorithm except that the priority queue is implemented by a Max Heap. Each round of the loop from line 9 to 19 extract the largest weight edge. And  is updated if . (15pts)
I think his algorithm is not correct.

When updating distances using the condition , the algorithm attempts to assign new values based on the assumption that there exists a greater path value from through to.
However, since all are initially , the algorithm's condition will always find that is false, because you cannot have a real number that is greater than . This results in no updates to .

From the lecture, Mr. Smart knows that Prim‚Äôs algorithm runs in time and Kruskal‚Äôs algorithm runs in  time. Then, Mr. Smart claims that the time complexity of Prim‚Äôs algorithm is lower than Kruskal‚Äôs algorithm. Is he correct? Prove your answer. (10pts)
I think he is not correct.


Prim's Algorithm: Actually as , where is the number of edges, and is the number of vertices.
Kruskal's Algorithm: Commonly has a complexity of .


In dense graphs, there are far more edges than vertices, for example .
The time complexity of Prim's algorithm is .
The time complexity of Kruskal's algorithm is .
In this case, the time complexity of Prim's algorithm is lower than Kruskal's algorithm.


In a sparse graph, the number of edges is close to the number of vertices, that is, .
The time complexity of Kruskal's algorithm is , because the number of edges is small, the sorting burden is relatively light.
The time complexity of Prim's algorithm is .
In this case, the time complexity of Kruskal's algorithm is lower than that of Prim algorithm.

Therefore, it cannot be said that the time complexity of Prim's algorithm is always lower than that of Kruskal's algorithm.

item.title: DAA-Assignment-1DAA-Assignment-1
item.description:
Given the input A=[11, -7, 8, 12, 6, 5, -6, 3] , track the divide-and-conquer algorithm to find the maximum contiguous subarray. You need to show the recursive calls as a tree. The input and output for each recursive call should also be indicated as well.

Input: A=[11, -7, 8, 12, 6, 5, -6, 3]
Output: MCS of A
Algorithm Maximum Contiguous Subarray Problem if i=ji = ji=j then return R[i]R[i]R[i] else s1‚ÜêMCS(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)s1 \gets \text{MCS}(R, i, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor)s1‚ÜêMCS(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)//Using floor function for lower rounding s2‚ÜêMCS(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j)s2 \gets \text{MCS}(R, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor + 1, j)s2‚ÜêMCS(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j) A‚ÜêMaxSuffix(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)+MaxPrefix(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j)A \gets \text{MaxSuffix}(R, i, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor) + \text{MaxPrefix}(R, \lfloor(i+j)/2\rfloor + 1, j)A‚ÜêMaxSuffix(R,i,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã)+MaxPrefix(R,‚åä(i+j)/2‚åã+1,j) return MAX(s1,s2,A)\text{MAX}(s1, s2, A)MAX(s1,s2,A) end if Export to clipboard


Given two polynomials and , track the  algorithm to calculate . You need to show the recursive calls as a tree. The input and output for each recursive call should also be indicated as well.

Input: Two polynomials A(X) and B(x) of order n
Output: The polynomial C(X) = A(x)B(x)

For Euclidean Algorithm to find GCD

Define the problem solved by the algorithm (6pt)
Input: 2 positive integer A,B
Output: A positive integer that is Greatest Common Divisor of A and B
Give a high-level presentation of the algorithm (6pt)
Divide the larger number by the smaller number, then remove the divisor by the remainder that occurs (the first remainder), then remove the first remainder by the remainder that occurs (the second remainder), and so on until the final remainder is zero. If you are finding the greatest common divisor of two numbers, then the final divisor is the greatest common divisor of those two numbers.

Insertion Time: To insert an element into an AVLAVL tree, we perform a binary search to find the correct position for the new element and then possibly perform some rotations to maintain the AVLAVL property. The time complexity of both these operations is ( O(log n) ) because the tree is balanced.
Building the Tree: If we insert ( n ) distinct integers into an AVLAVL tree, each insert operation takes ( O(log n) ) time. Since there are ( n ) elements, the total time to build the tree is ( O(n log n) ).
In-order Traversal: Once the AVLAVL tree is built, we can perform an in-order traversal to retrieve the elements in sorted order. An in-order traversal of a binary search tree visits the nodes in ascending order, which is what we want for sorting. The time complexity for in-order traversal is ( O(n) ), as each node is visited exactly once.
Total Time Complexity: The total time complexity of sorting an array using an AVLAVL tree is the time to build the tree (( O(n log n) )) plus the time for the in-order traversal (( O(n) )). Hence, the overall time complexity is ( O(n log n) ).
Therefore, we have shown that using an AVLAVL tree to sort an array of distinct integers has a time complexity of ( O(n log n) ).

( M = 171 ): Each internal node can have up to 171 children (170 keys + 1 extra pointer).

item.title: Tree
item.description:
Basic Concepts
Binary Trees
Binary Search Trees

A tree is a collection of nodes

The collection can be empty
(recursive definition) If not empty, a tree consists of a distinguished node r (the root), and zero or more nonempty subtrees , each of whose roots are connected by a directed edge from root
Concept

Root and Leaf
Child and Parent
Every node except the root has one parent
A node can have an zero or more children
A leaf node has no children
Sibling
nodes with same parent
Path

a sequence of edges
Length of a path
Depth of a node

length of the unique path to the root
Height of a node

length of the longest path to a leaf
Tree height

the height of the root
the depth of the deepest leaf
Ancestor and descendant

If there is a path from n1 to n2
n1 is an ancestor of n2, n2 is a descendant of n1
Proper ancestor and proper descendant

A perfect binary tree is the tree where a node can have 0 or 2 children and all leaves are at the same depth
item.dc:creator: AllenYGY

item.description:
Binary search tree has one key to decide which of the two branches to take
M-ary search tree needs M-1 keys to decide which branch to take
M-ary search tree should be balanced in some way.
We don‚Äôt want an M-ary search tree to degenerate to a linked list, or even a binary search tree
Thus, require that each node is at least half full!


A B+ tree of order M
Each internal node has at most M children (M-1 keys)
Each internal node, except the root, has between and keys
Each leaf has between keys and corresponding data items


A of order M (M>3) is an M-ary tree with the following properties:
The data items are stored in leaves
The root is either a leaf or has between two and M children
The non-leaf nodes store up to M-1 keys to guide the searching; key i represents the smallest key in subtree i+1
All non-leaf nodes (except the root) have between and M children
All leaves are at the same depth and have between and L data items, for some L (usually L << M, but we will assume M=L in most examples)
Keys in internal Nodes
key i in an internal node is the smallest key in its i+1 subtree (i.e. right subtree of key i)



Suppose that we want to insert a key K and its associated record.
Search for the key K using the search procedure. This will bring us to a leaf x
Insert K into x
Insert Into Leaf

If leaf x contains < L keys, then insert K into x (at the correct position in node x)
If x is already full (i.e. containing L keys) then split x
Cut x off from its parent
Insert K into x, pretending x has space for K. Now x has L+1 keys.
After inserting K, split x into 2 new leaves and , with containing the smallest keys, and containing the remaining keys. Let J be the minimum key in
Make a copy of J to be the parent of and , and insert the copy together with its child pointers into the old parent of x.
Insert Into Internal Node When leaf is Full and Internal Node is also Full
To insert a key K into a full internal node x:

Cut x off from its parent
Insert K and its left and right child pointers into x, pretending there is space. Now x has M keys (and M+1 pointers).
Split x into 2 new internal nodes and , with containing the smallest keys, and containing the largest keys. Note that the key J is not placed in or
Make J the parent of xL and xR, and insert J together with its child pointers into the old parent of x.

Situation I:

The target is a key in some internal node (needs to be replaced, according to our convention)
Situation II:

After deleting target from leaf x, x contains less than keys (needs to merge nodes)

After deleting from node x, we can access y directly and replace target by the new smallest key in x

Let u be the leaf that has keys (too few)
Let v be a sibling of u with at least keys
Let k be the key in the parent of u and v that separates the pointers to u and v
There are two cases

Case 1: v contains or more keys and v is the right sibling of u
Move the leftmost record from v to u

v contains or more keys and v is the left sibling of u
Move the rightmost record from v to u
Then set the key in parent of u that separates u and v to be the new smallest key in u

vector<int> topo_sort(int k, vector<vector<int>> &edges) { vector<vector<int>> g(k); vector<int> in_deg(k); for (auto &e : edges) { int x = e[0], y = e[1] ; // È°∂ÁÇπÁºñÂè∑‰ªé 0 ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊñπ‰æøËÆ°ÁÆó g[x].push_back(y); ++in_deg[y]; } vector<int> order; queue<int> q; for (int i = 0; i < k; ++i) if (in_deg[i] == 0) q.push(i); while (!q.empty()) { int x = q.front(); q.pop(); order.push_back(x); for (int y : g[x]) if (--in_deg[y] == 0) q.push(y); } return order; } Copy

vector<int> prime; bool is_prime[N]; void Eratosthenes(int n) { is_prime[0] = is_prime[1] = false; for (int i = 2; i <= n; ++i) is_prime[i] = true; for (int i = 2; i <= n; ++i) { if (is_prime[i]) { prime.push_back(i); if ((long long)i * i > n) continue; for (int j = i * i; j <= n; j += i) // Âõ†‰∏∫‰ªé 2 Âà∞ i - 1 ÁöÑÂÄçÊï∞Êàë‰ª¨‰πãÂâçÁ≠õËøá‰∫ÜÔºåËøôÈáåÁõ¥Êé•‰ªé i // ÁöÑÂÄçÊï∞ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊèêÈ´ò‰∫ÜËøêË°åÈÄüÂ∫¶ is_prime[j] = false; // ÊòØ i ÁöÑÂÄçÊï∞ÁöÑÂùá‰∏çÊòØÁ¥†Êï∞ } } } Copy

vector<int> pri; bool not_prime[N]; void pre(int n) { for (int i = 2; i <= n; ++i) { if (!not_prime[i]) pri.push_back(i); for (int pri_j : pri) { if (i * pri_j > n) break; not_prime[i * pri_j] = true; if (i % pri_j == 0) { // i % pri_j == 0 // Êç¢Ë®Ä‰πãÔºåi ‰πãÂâçË¢´ pri_j Á≠õËøá‰∫Ü // Áî±‰∫é pri ÈáåÈù¢Ë¥®Êï∞ÊòØ‰ªéÂ∞èÂà∞Â§ßÁöÑÔºåÊâÄ‰ª• i ‰πò‰∏äÂÖ∂‰ªñÁöÑË¥®Êï∞ÁöÑÁªìÊûú‰∏ÄÂÆö‰ºöË¢´ // pri_j ÁöÑÂÄçÊï∞Á≠õÊéâÔºåÂ∞±‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂú®ËøôÈáåÂÖàÁ≠õ‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ËøôÈáåÁõ¥Êé• break // ÊéâÂ∞±Â•Ω‰∫Ü break; } } } } Copy

item.description:

ÂàöÂºÄÂßãÁõ¥Êé•Â∑¶Âè≥ËäÇÁÇπÂàÜÂà´ÈÅçÂéÜÔºåÂèñÊúÄÂ∞èÂÄº
Ê≤°ËÄÉËôëÊ†πËäÇÁÇπÂè™Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂàÜÊîØÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµ
class Solution { public: int minDepth(TreeNode* root) { if(root==nullptr) return 0; int left = minDepth(root->left); int right = minDepth(root->right); return min(left,right)+1; } }; Copy
ÊØè‰∏ÄÂ±ÇÁöÑÊÉÖÂÜµÈÄíÂΩíÊó∂Ê≤°ÊúâÂä†‰∏Ä
class Solution { public: int minDepth(TreeNode* root) { if(root->left==nullptr&&root->right==nullptr) return 1; else if(root->left==nullptr&&root->right!=nullptr) return minDepth(root->right); else if(root->left!=nullptr&&root->right==nullptr) return minDepth(root->left); else return min(minDepth(root->right),minDepth(root->left)); } }; Copy
class Solution { public: int minDepth(TreeNode* root) { if(root==nullptr)return 0; if(root->left==nullptr && root->right==nullptr) return 1; int m1=minDepth(root->right); int m2=minDepth(root->left); if(root->left==nullptr||root->right==nullptr) return m1+m2+1; return min(m1,m2)+1; } }; Copy

#Experience
Âè∂Â≠êËäÇÁÇπÁöÑÂÆö‰πâ
node->left==nullptr&&node->right==nullptr Copy
class Solution { public: bool hasPathSum(TreeNode* root, int targetSum) { if(root==nullptr)return false; if(root->left==nullptr&&root->right==nullptr) return targetSum==root->val; bool l = hasPathSum(root->left,targetSum-root->val); bool r = hasPathSum(root->right,targetSum-root->val); return l||r; } }; Copy

#achievement
Á¨¨‰∏ÄÊ¨°Áã¨Á´ãÂÜôÂá∫ÔºåÈÄíÂΩíÔºåÂõûÊ∫ØÔºüÂìàÂìàÂìàÂìà
class Solution { vector<vector<int>> res; vector<int> v; public: void dfs(TreeNode* root, int targetSum) { if(root==nullptr) return ; if(root->left==nullptr&&root->right==nullptr) if(targetSum==root->val){ v.push_back(root->val); res.push_back(v); v.pop_back(); } if(root->left){ v.push_back(root->val); dfs(root->left,targetSum-root->val); v.pop_back(); } if(root->right){ v.push_back(root->val); dfs(root->right,targetSum-root->val); v.pop_back(); } } vector<vector<int>> pathSum(TreeNode* root, int targetSum) { if(root==nullptr)return {}; dfs(root,targetSum); return res; } }; Copy

class Solution { vector<vector<int>>res; vector<int>v; public: void dfs(TreeNode* root){ if(root->left==nullptr&&root->right==nullptr){ v.push_back(root->val); res.push_back(v); v.pop_back(); } if(root->left){ v.push_back(root->val); dfs(root->left); v.pop_back(); } if(root->right){ v.push_back(root->val); dfs(root->right); v.pop_back(); } } int sumNumbers(TreeNode* root) { if(root==nullptr)return 0; dfs(root); int ans=0; for(auto row:res){ int tmp=0; for(int num:row){ tmp=((tmp*10)+num); } ans+=tmp; } return ans; } }; Copy
ÂÆòËß£ÁÆÄÊ¥ÅÂÜôÊ≥ï
class Solution { public: int dfs(TreeNode* root, int prevSum) { if (root == nullptr) { return 0; } int sum = prevSum * 10 + root->val; if (root->left == nullptr && root->right == nullptr){ return sum; } else { return dfs(root->left, sum) + dfs(root->right,sum); } } int sumNumbers(TreeNode* root) { return dfs(root, 0); } }; Copy

#Experience
ÊääÂèòÈáèÂΩì‰ΩúÂèÇÊï∞‰º†ÈÄíËøõÂáΩÊï∞ÔºåÂàô‰∏çÈúÄË¶ÅÂõûÊ∫ØÂèòÈáè
class Solution { public: void construct_paths(TreeNode* root, string path, vector<string>& paths) { if (root != nullptr) { path += to_string(root->val); if (root->left == nullptr && root->right == nullptr) { // ÂΩìÂâçËäÇÁÇπÊòØÂè∂Â≠êËäÇÁÇπ paths.push_back(path); // ÊääË∑ØÂæÑÂä†ÂÖ•Âà∞Á≠îÊ°à‰∏≠ } else { path += "->"; // ÂΩìÂâçËäÇÁÇπ‰∏çÊòØÂè∂Â≠êËäÇÁÇπÔºåÁªßÁª≠ÈÄíÂΩíÈÅçÂéÜ construct_paths(root->left, path, paths); construct_paths(root->right, path, paths); } } } vector<string> binaryTreePaths(TreeNode* root) { vector<string> paths; construct_paths(root, "", paths); return paths; } }; Copy

class Solution { public: int goodNodes(TreeNode* root,int mx=INT_MIN) { if(root==nullptr) return 0; int left = goodNodes(root->left,max(mx,root->val)); int right = goodNodes(root->right, max(mx,root->val)); return left+right+(mx<=root->val); } }; Copy

#Experience
ÂÖàÈÅçÂéÜÂè≥Â≠êÊ†ëÂπ∂Ê†πÊçÆÊ∑±Â∫¶ÂÜ≥ÂÆöÊòØÂê¶ËÆ∞ÂΩïËØ•ËäÇÁÇπ
class Solution { vector<int>ans; public: void dfs(TreeNode* root,int depth){ if(depth==ans.size()) ans.push_back(root->val); if(root->right) dfs(root->right,depth+1); if(root->left) dfs(root->left,depth+1); } vector<int> rightSideView(TreeNode* root) { if(root==nullptr)return {}; dfs(root,0); return ans; } }; Copy

#Experience
ÂºÄÂßãÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÁäπË±´ÂΩìÂâçËäÇÁÇπÂà§Êñ≠ÔºåÂ∑¶Â≠êÊ†ëÂà§Êñ≠ÂíåÂè≥Â≠êÊ†ëÂà§Êñ≠
ÂêéÊù•ÂèëÁé∞Âπ∂ÂàóÂ∞±Â•Ω‰∫Ü
class Solution { public: bool isSameTree(TreeNode* p, TreeNode* q) { if(p==nullptr||q==nullptr)return (p==q); return (p->val==q->val)&&(isSameTree(p->left,q->left))&&(isSameTree(p->right,q->right)); } }; Copy

class Solution { public: bool isSame(TreeNode* p,TreeNode *q){ if(p==nullptr||q==nullptr)return (p==q); return (p->val==q->val)&&isSame(p->left,q->right)&&isSame(p->right,q->left); } bool isSymmetric(TreeNode* root) { return isSame(root->left,root->right); } }; Copy

class Solution { public: int get_height(TreeNode *node){ if(node==nullptr)return 0; int leftH = get_height(node->left); if(leftH==-1) return -1; int rightH = get_height(node->right); if(rightH==-1||abs(leftH-rightH)>1)return -1; return max(leftH,rightH)+1; } bool isBalanced(TreeNode* root) { return get_height(root)!=-1; } }; Copy

class Solution { public: TreeNode* invertTree(TreeNode* root) { if(root==nullptr)return nullptr; root->left=invertTree(root->left); root->right=invertTree(root->right); TreeNode*tmp=root->left; root->left=root->right; root->right=tmp; return root; } }; Copy

#Experience

ÊàëÁêÜËß£Âà∞ÔºåÂè™ËÉΩÂÖàÂà†Âè∂Â≠êËäÇÁÇπ
Âà§Êñ≠Âè∂Â≠êËäÇÁÇπ
if (root->left == root->right) Copy

Â¶ÇÊûú limit > 0 ËØ¥Êòé‰ªéÊ†πÂà∞Âè∂Â≠êÁöÑË∑ØÂæÑÂíåÂ∞è‰∫é limitÔºåÂà†Èô§Âè∂Â≠êÔºåÂê¶Âàô‰∏çÂà†Èô§
Â¶ÇÊûúÊúâÂÑøÂ≠êÊ≤°Ë¢´Âà†Èô§ÔºåÂ∞±‰∏çÂà† rootÔºåÂê¶ÂàôÂà† root
Âà§Êñ≠ÊòØÂê¶Â≠òÂú®Â≠êËäÇÁÇπ
if(root->left || root->right) Copy
class Solution { public: TreeNode* sufficientSubset(TreeNode* root, int limit) { limit -= root->val; if (root->left == root->right) return limit > 0 ? nullptr : root; if(root->left) root->left = sufficientSubset(root->left, limit); if(root->right) root->right = sufficientSubset(root->right, limit); return root->left || root->right ? root : nullptr; } }; Copy

class Solution { int ans = 0; // Áî®‰∫éËÆ∞ÂΩïÊúÄÂ§ßÈïøÂ∫¶ÁöÑÂÖ®Â±ÄÂèòÈáè void getlongestZigZag(TreeNode* root, bool is_left, int len) { if (root == nullptr) { ans = max(ans, len); // Êõ¥Êñ∞ÊúÄÂ§ßÈïøÂ∫¶ return; } // ÈÄíÂΩíÂú∞Âú®Â∑¶Âè≥Â≠êÊ†ë‰∏≠Êü•Êâæ‰∫§ÈîôË∑ØÂæÑ if (is_left) { // Â¶ÇÊûúÂΩìÂâçÊñπÂêëÊòØÂ∑¶ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂú®Âè≥Â≠êÊ†ë‰∏≠ÁªßÁª≠Êâæ‰∫§ÈîôË∑ØÂæÑÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÈïøÂ∫¶Âä†‰∏Ä getlongestZigZag(root->right, false, len + 1); // ÂêëÂè≥Ëµ∞ getlongestZigZag(root->left, true, 1); // ÈáçÊñ∞ÂºÄÂßãËÆ°Êï∞ } else { // Â¶ÇÊûúÂΩìÂâçÊñπÂêëÊòØÂè≥ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂú®Â∑¶Â≠êÊ†ë‰∏≠ÁªßÁª≠Êâæ‰∫§ÈîôË∑ØÂæÑÔºåÂπ∂‰∏îÈïøÂ∫¶Âä†‰∏Ä getlongestZigZag(root->left, true, len + 1); // ÂêëÂ∑¶Ëµ∞ getlongestZigZag(root->right, false, 1); // ÈáçÊñ∞ÂºÄÂßãËÆ°Êï∞ } } public: int longestZigZag(TreeNode* root) { getlongestZigZag(root->left, true, 1); // ÂΩìÊàë‰ª¨‰ªéÊ†πËäÇÁÇπÂêëÂ∑¶ÁßªÂä®Êó∂ÔºåË∑ØÂæÑÈïøÂ∫¶Âèò‰∏∫1 getlongestZigZag(root->right, false, 1); // ÂêåÁêÜÔºåÂΩìÊàë‰ª¨‰ªéÊ†πËäÇÁÇπÂêëÂè≥ÁßªÂä®Êó∂ÔºåË∑ØÂæÑÈïøÂ∫¶Âèò‰∏∫1 return ans -1; // Âõ†‰∏∫ÈïøÂ∫¶ÊòØ‰ªé1ÂºÄÂßãÁöÑÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÂáèÂéª1 } }; Copy

item.description:
Á®ãÂ∫èË∞ÉÁî®Ëá™Ë∫´ÁöÑÁºñÁ®ãÊäÄÂ∑ßÁß∞‰∏∫ÈÄíÂΩí Recursion

ÈÄíÂΩí‰Ωú‰∏∫‰∏ÄÁßçÁÆóÊ≥ïÂú®Á®ãÂ∫èËÆæËÆ°ËØ≠Ë®Ä‰∏≠ÂπøÊ≥õÂ∫îÁî®„ÄÇ
‰∏Ä‰∏™ËøáÁ®ãÊàñÂáΩÊï∞Âú®ÂÖ∂ÂÆö‰πâÊàñËØ¥Êòé‰∏≠ÊúâÁõ¥Êé•ÊàñÈó¥Êé•Ë∞ÉÁî®Ëá™Ë∫´ÁöÑ‰∏ÄÁßçÊñπÊ≥ïÔºåÂÆÉÈÄöÂ∏∏Êää‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ßÂûãÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÂ±ÇÂ±ÇËΩ¨Âåñ‰∏∫‰∏Ä‰∏™‰∏éÂéüÈóÆÈ¢òÁõ∏‰ººÁöÑËßÑÊ®°ËæÉÂ∞èÁöÑÈóÆÈ¢òÊù•Ê±ÇËß£„ÄÇ
ÈÄíÂΩíÁ≠ñÁï•Âè™ÈúÄÂ∞ëÈáèÁöÑÁ®ãÂ∫èÂ∞±ÂèØÊèèËø∞Âá∫Ëß£È¢òËøáÁ®ãÊâÄÈúÄË¶ÅÁöÑÂ§öÊ¨°ÈáçÂ§çËÆ°ÁÆóÔºåÂ§ßÂ§ßÂú∞ÂáèÂ∞ë‰∫ÜÁ®ãÂ∫èÁöÑ‰ª£Á†ÅÈáè„ÄÇ
‰∏ÄËà¨Êù•ËØ¥ÔºåÈÄíÂΩíÈúÄË¶ÅÊúâËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂„ÄÅÈÄíÂΩíÂâçËøõÊÆµÂíåÈÄíÂΩíËøîÂõûÊÆµ„ÄÇ
ÂΩìËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂‰∏çÊª°Ë∂≥Êó∂ÔºåÈÄíÂΩíÂâçËøõÔºõÂΩìËæπÁïåÊù°‰ª∂Êª°Ë∂≥Êó∂ÔºåÈÄíÂΩíËøîÂõû„ÄÇ
ÈÄíÂΩíÁöÑËÉΩÂäõÂú®‰∫éÁî®ÊúâÈôêÁöÑËØ≠Âè•Êù•ÂÆö‰πâÂØπË±°ÁöÑÊó†ÈôêÈõÜÂêà„ÄÇ

ÈÄíÂΩíÔºö‰Ω†ÊâìÂºÄÈù¢ÂâçËøôÊâáÈó®ÔºåÁúãÂà∞Â±ãÈáåÈù¢ËøòÊúâ‰∏ÄÊâáÈó®„ÄÇ‰Ω†Ëµ∞ËøáÂéªÔºåÂèëÁé∞Êâã‰∏≠ÁöÑÈí•ÂåôËøòÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÂºÄÂÆÉÔºå‰Ω†Êé®ÂºÄÈó®ÔºåÂèëÁé∞ÈáåÈù¢ËøòÊúâ‰∏ÄÊâáÈó®Ôºå‰Ω†ÁªßÁª≠ÊâìÂºÄÂÆÉ„ÄÇËã•Âπ≤Ê¨°‰πãÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÊâìÂºÄÈù¢ÂâçÁöÑÈó®ÂêéÔºåÂèëÁé∞Âè™Êúâ‰∏ÄÈó¥Â±ãÂ≠êÔºåÊ≤°ÊúâÈó®‰∫Ü„ÄÇÁÑ∂ÂêéÔºå‰Ω†ÂºÄÂßãÂéüË∑ØËøîÂõûÔºåÊØèËµ∞Âõû‰∏ÄÈó¥Â±ãÂ≠êÔºå‰Ω†Êï∞‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÔºåËµ∞Âà∞ÂÖ•Âè£ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºå‰Ω†ÂèØ‰ª•ÂõûÁ≠îÂá∫‰Ω†Âà∞Â∫ïÁî®Ëøô‰Ω†ÊääÈí•ÂåôÊâìÂºÄ‰∫ÜÂá†ÊâáÈó®„ÄÇ
Âæ™ÁéØÔºö‰Ω†ÊâìÂºÄÈù¢ÂâçËøôÊâáÈó®ÔºåÁúãÂà∞Â±ãÈáåÈù¢ËøòÊúâ‰∏ÄÊâáÈó®„ÄÇ‰Ω†Ëµ∞ËøáÂéªÔºåÂèëÁé∞Êâã‰∏≠ÁöÑÈí•ÂåôËøòÂèØ‰ª•ÊâìÂºÄÂÆÉÔºå‰Ω†Êé®ÂºÄÈó®ÔºåÂèëÁé∞ÈáåÈù¢ËøòÊúâ‰∏ÄÊâáÈó®ÔºàËã•ÂâçÈù¢‰∏§ÊâáÈó®ÈÉΩ‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàËøôÊâáÈó®ÂíåÂâç‰∏§ÊâáÈó®‰πü‰∏ÄÊ†∑ÔºõÂ¶ÇÊûúÁ¨¨‰∫åÊâáÈó®ÊØîÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÊâáÈó®Â∞èÔºåÈÇ£‰πàËøôÊâáÈó®‰πüÊØîÁ¨¨‰∫åÊâáÈó®Â∞èÔºå‰Ω†ÁªßÁª≠ÊâìÂºÄËøôÊâáÈó®Ôºå‰∏ÄÁõ¥ËøôÊ†∑ÁªßÁª≠‰∏ãÂéªÁõ¥Âà∞ÊâìÂºÄÊâÄÊúâÁöÑÈó®„ÄÇ‰ΩÜÊòØÔºåÂÖ•Âè£Â§ÑÁöÑ‰∫∫ÂßãÁªàÁ≠â‰∏çÂà∞‰Ω†ÂõûÂéªÂëäËØâ‰ªñÁ≠îÊ°à„ÄÇ

1. ÊòéÁ°ÆÈÄíÂΩíÁªàÊ≠¢Êù°‰ª∂ÔºàÈÄíÂΩíÂá∫Âè£Ôºâ
Êàë‰ª¨Áü•ÈÅìÔºåÈÄíÂΩíÂ∞±ÊòØÊúâÂéªÊúâÂõûÔºåÊó¢ÁÑ∂ËøôÊ†∑ÔºåÈÇ£‰πàÂøÖÁÑ∂Â∫îËØ•Êúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊòéÁ°ÆÁöÑ‰∏¥ÁïåÁÇπÔºåÁ®ãÂ∫è‰∏ÄÊó¶Âà∞Ëææ‰∫ÜËøô‰∏™‰∏¥ÁïåÁÇπÔºåÂ∞±‰∏çÁî®ÁªßÁª≠ÂæÄ‰∏ãÈÄíÂéªËÄåÊòØÂºÄÂßãÂÆûÂÆûÂú®Âú®ÁöÑÂΩíÊù•„ÄÇÊç¢Âè•ËØùËØ¥ÔºåËØ•‰∏¥ÁïåÁÇπÂ∞±ÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁÆÄÂçïÊÉÖÂ¢ÉÔºåÂèØ‰ª•Èò≤Ê≠¢Êó†ÈôêÈÄíÂΩí„ÄÇ
2. ÁªôÂá∫ÈÄíÂΩíÁªàÊ≠¢Êó∂ÁöÑÂ§ÑÁêÜÂäûÊ≥ï
Êàë‰ª¨ÂàöÂàöËØ¥Âà∞ÔºåÂú®ÈÄíÂΩíÁöÑ‰∏¥ÁïåÁÇπÂ≠òÂú®‰∏ÄÁßçÁÆÄÂçïÊÉÖÂ¢ÉÔºåÂú®ËøôÁßçÁÆÄÂçïÊÉÖÂ¢É‰∏ãÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Â∫îËØ•Áõ¥Êé•ÁªôÂá∫ÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°à„ÄÇ‰∏ÄËà¨Âú∞ÔºåÂú®ËøôÁßçÊÉÖÂ¢É‰∏ãÔºåÈóÆÈ¢òÁöÑËß£ÂÜ≥ÊñπÊ°àÊòØÁõ¥ËßÇÁöÑ„ÄÅÂÆπÊòìÁöÑ„ÄÇ
3. ÊèêÂèñÈáçÂ§çÁöÑÈÄªËæëÔºåÁº©Â∞èÈóÆÈ¢òËßÑÊ®°
Êàë‰ª¨Âú®ÈòêËø∞ÈÄíÂΩíÊÄùÊÉ≥ÂÜÖÊ∂µÊó∂Ë∞àÂà∞ÔºåÈÄíÂΩíÈóÆÈ¢òÂøÖÈ°ªÂèØ‰ª•ÂàÜËß£‰∏∫Ëã•Âπ≤‰∏™ËßÑÊ®°ËæÉÂ∞è„ÄÅ‰∏éÂéüÈóÆÈ¢òÂΩ¢ÂºèÁõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÂ≠êÈóÆÈ¢òÔºåËøô‰∫õÂ≠êÈóÆÈ¢òÂèØ‰ª•Áî®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑËß£È¢òÊÄùË∑ØÊù•Ëß£ÂÜ≥„ÄÇ‰ªéÁ®ãÂ∫èÂÆûÁé∞ÁöÑËßíÂ∫¶ËÄåË®ÄÔºåÊàë‰ª¨ÈúÄË¶ÅÊäΩË±°Âá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Âπ≤ÂáÄÂà©ËêΩÁöÑÈáçÂ§çÁöÑÈÄªËæëÔºå‰ª•‰æø‰ΩøÁî®Áõ∏ÂêåÁöÑÊñπÂºèËß£ÂÜ≥Â≠êÈóÆÈ¢ò„ÄÇ



Êü≥Â∑û‰º†ËØ¥ÊòØÊ≠å‰ªôÂàò‰∏âÂßêÁöÑ‰º†Ê≠å‰πãÂú∞ÔºåÊúÄËøë‰∏æÂäû‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÊ¨°Â±±Ê≠åÂ§ßËµõ„ÄÇ Âú®Ëøô‰∏™È°πÁõÆ‰∏≠ÔºåÂèÇËµõËÄÖÊØèÊ¨°ÂÆåÊàê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊÆµÈÉΩ‰ºöÂæóÂà∞‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂàÜÊï∞„ÄÇÊÄªÂàÜÊï∞ÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóÊñπÂºèÂü∫‰∫é‰∏Ä‰∏™ÁâπÊÆä ÁöÑÊï∞Â≠¶Ë°®ËææÂºè f(x,n)„ÄÇË°®ËææÂºè f(x,n) ÁöÑÂÆö‰πâÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÔºö

ÂÖ∂‰∏≠Ôºåx Ë°®Á§∫ÂèÇËµõËÄÖÁöÑÂü∫Êú¨ÂæóÂàÜÔºån Ë°®Á§∫ÂèÇËµõËÄÖÂÆåÊàêÁöÑÂ±±Ê≠åÊÆµËêΩÊï∞„ÄÇ
Ê¥•Ê¥•„ÄÅËè≤Ëè≤ÂíåÁöÆÁöÆÁöÑ‰ªªÂä°ÊòØÁºñÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∏™Á®ãÂ∫èÔºåÂπ∂ËÆ°ÁÆóÈÄâÊâã AÔºàx=4.2,n=10Ôºâ„ÄÅÈÄâÊâã BÔºàx=2.5,n=15Ôºâ Êó∂ f(x,n)ÁöÑÂÄº

ËæìÂÖ•xÂíån„ÄÇ

ÂáΩÊï∞ÂÄºÔºå‰øùÁïô‰∏§‰ΩçÂ∞èÊï∞„ÄÇ

Input
4.2 10 Copy
Output
3.68 Copy

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; double f(double x, int n){ if(n==1) return sqrt(1+x); return sqrt(n+f(x,n-1)); } signed main() { double x; int n; cin>>x>>n; cout<<fixed<<setprecision(2)<<f(x,n)<<endl; return 0; } Copy


Áî®ÈÄíÂΩíÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÊ±Ç Hermite Â§öÈ°πÂºèÁöÑÂÄº„ÄÇ


ÁªôÂÆöÁöÑ ÂíåÊ≠£Êï¥Êï∞

ÂØπÁªôÂÆöÁöÑ ÂíåÊ≠£Êï¥Êï∞ ÔºåÊ±ÇÂ§öÈ°πÂºèÁöÑÂÄº„ÄÇ

Input
1 2 Copy
Output
4.00 Copy

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; double h(double x, int n){ if(n==0) return 1; if(n==1) return 2*x; return 2*x*h(x,n-1)-2*(n-1)*h(x,n-2); } signed main() { int n; double x; cin>>n>>x; cout<<fixed<<setprecision(2)<<h(x,n)<<endl; return 0; } Copy


Êúâ‰∏ÄÂ§¥ÊØçÁâõÔºå‰ªéÁ¨¨‰∫åÂπ¥Ëµ∑ÔºåÂÆÉÊØèÂπ¥Âπ¥ÂàùÁîü‰∏ÄÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ„ÄÇÊØèÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ‰ªéÁ¨¨Âõõ‰∏™Âπ¥Â§¥ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊØèÂπ¥Âπ¥Âàù‰πüÁîü‰∏ÄÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ„ÄÇËØ∑ÁºñÁ®ãÂÆûÁé∞Âú®Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÂ§¥ÊØçÁâõÔºü

ËæìÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆÁî±Â§ö‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÁªÑÊàêÔºåÊØè‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÂç†‰∏ÄË°åÔºåÂåÖÊã¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞n(0<n<55)ÔºånÁöÑÂê´‰πâÂ¶ÇÈ¢òÁõÆ‰∏≠ÊèèËø∞„ÄÇ
n=0Ë°®Á§∫ËæìÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÁªìÊùüÔºå‰∏çÂÅöÂ§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÇ

ÂØπ‰∫éÊØè‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÔºåËæìÂá∫Âú®Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÊØçÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè„ÄÇÊØè‰∏™ËæìÂá∫Âç†‰∏ÄË°å„ÄÇ

Input
2 4 5 0 Copy
Output
2 4 6 Copy

Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè‰∏∫Ôºön-1Âπ¥ÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÂíå‰ªäÂπ¥Êñ∞Âá∫ÁîüÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè
‰ªäÂπ¥Êñ∞Âá∫ÁîüÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè‰∏∫ n-3 Âπ¥ÂâçÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè

#include <bits/stdc++.h> #include <iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; const int MOD = 1000; const int MAXN = 1000000; int val[MAXN] = {0}; void solve(int x) { if(val[x]!=0){ cout << val[x] << endl; return; } val[1]=1; val[2]=2; val[3]=3; for(int i=4;i<=x;i++){ val[i]=(val[i-1]+val[i-3]); } cout << val[x] << endl; } signed main() { int x; cin >> x; while (x) { solve(x); cin >> x; } return 0; } Copy

item.title: ÈÄíÊé®ÈÄíÊé®
item.description:
ÈÄíÊé®ÊòØÊåâÁÖß‰∏ÄÂÆöÁöÑËßÑÂæãÊù•Ê±ÇÂ∫èÂàó‰∏≠ÁöÑÊØè‰∏ÄÈ°π,‰∏ÄËà¨ÊòØÈÄöËøáËÆ°ÁÆóÂâçÈù¢ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∫õÈ°πÊù•ÂæóÂá∫Â∫èÂàó‰∏≠ÁöÑÊåáÂÆöÈ°π„ÄÇ
ÂÖ∂ÊÄùÊÉ≥ÊòØÊää‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§çÊùÇÁöÑÂ∫ûÂ§ßÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆóËøáÁ®ãËΩ¨Âåñ‰∏∫ÂØπÁÆÄÂçïËøáÁ®ãÁöÑÂ§öÊ¨°ÈáçÂ§ç,ËØ•ÁÆóÊ≥ïÂà©Áî®‰∫ÜËÆ°ÁÆóÊú∫ËøêÁÆóÈÄüÂ∫¶Âø´Âíå‰∏çÁü•Áñ≤ÂÄ¶ÁöÑÊú∫Âô®ÁâπÁÇπ„ÄÇ


Â∞ÜÈóÆÈ¢òÁî®Êï∞ÁªÑÂΩ¢ÂºèË°®Ëææ
Ê±ÇËß£ÈÄíÊé®ÂÖ≥Á≥ª,ÂàóÂá∫ÈÄíÊé®Ë°®ËææÂºè
ÂØªÊâæËæπÁïåÂÄº


È¶ñÂÖàÁü•ÈÅìÂ∞èËßÑÊ®°ÁöÑÊï∞Âàó
Ê±ÇËß£ÈÄíÊé®ÂÖ≥Á≥ª,ÂàóÂá∫ÈÄíÊé®Ë°®ËææÂºè

üê∞ÁöÑÊïÖ‰∫ã Â∑≤Áü•‰∏ÄÂØπÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÊØè‰∏™ÊúàÂèØ‰ª•Áîü‰∏ÄÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠êÂá∫ÁîüÂêéÁöÑÁ¨¨‰∫å‰∏™Êúà‰ºöÂèòÊàêÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂ≠êÔºå‰ºöÁªßÁª≠ÁîüÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠ê„ÄÇ
Á¨¨‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ1ÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠ê„ÄÇ
Á¨¨‰∫å‰∏™ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ1ÂØπÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂ≠êÁöÑÂÖîÂ≠ê„ÄÇ
Á¨¨‰∏â‰∏™ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ1ÂØπÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂ≠êÁöÑÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÊúâ1ÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÂÖ±2ÂØπ„ÄÇ
Á¨¨Âõõ‰∏™ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ2ÂØπÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂ≠êÁöÑÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÊúâ1ÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÂÖ±3ÂØπ„ÄÇ
Á¨¨‰∫î‰∏™ÊúàÔºåÊàë‰ª¨Êúâ3ÂØπÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂ≠êÁöÑÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÊúâ2ÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠êÔºåÂÖ±5ÂØπ„ÄÇ
Áé∞Âú®Êàë‰ª¨Â∏åÊúõÁü•ÈÅìÁ¨¨n‰∏™ÊúàÔºå‰∏ÄÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÂè™ÂÖîÂ≠ê„ÄÇ
È¢òËß£ ÂÅáËÆæÔºöÁ¨¨‰∏™ÊúàÁöÑÂ§ßÂÖî‰∏∫ÂπºÂÖî‰∏∫,ÊÄªÊï∞. Â∑≤Áü•Ôºö‰∏ÄÂØπÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÊØè‰∏™ÊúàÂèØ‰ª•Áîü‰∏ÄÂØπÂ∞èÂÖîÂ≠ê Â∑≤Áü•Ôºö‰∏ã‰∏™ÊúàÁöÑÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÊòØÁî±‰∏ä‰∏™ÊúàÁöÑÊàêÂπ¥ÂÖîÂíåÂπºÂÖîÁªÑÊàêÁöÑ


#include <bits/stdc++.h> #include <iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; const int MOD = 1000; const int MAXN = 1000000; int val[MAXN] = {0}; val[1]=1, val[2]=1; signed main() { int n; cin >> n; if(val[n]!=0){ cout << val[n] << endl; return 0; } for(int i=3;i<=x;i++){ val[i]=(val[i-1]+val[i-2])%MOD; } cout << val[x] << endl; return 0; } Copy

ÊØçÁâõÁöÑÊïÖ‰∫ã Êúâ‰∏ÄÂ§¥ÊØçÁâõÔºå‰ªéÁ¨¨‰∫åÂπ¥Ëµ∑ÔºåÂÆÉÊØèÂπ¥Âπ¥ÂàùÁîü‰∏ÄÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ„ÄÇÊØèÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ‰ªéÁ¨¨Âõõ‰∏™Âπ¥Â§¥ÂºÄÂßãÔºåÊØèÂπ¥Âπ¥Âàù‰πüÁîü‰∏ÄÂ§¥Â∞èÊØçÁâõ„ÄÇËØ∑ÁºñÁ®ãÂÆûÁé∞Âú®Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÂ§¥ÊØçÁâõÔºü ËæìÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆÁî±Â§ö‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÁªÑÊàêÔºåÊØè‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÂç†‰∏ÄË°åÔºåÂåÖÊã¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞n(0<n<55)ÔºånÁöÑÂê´‰πâÂ¶ÇÈ¢òÁõÆ‰∏≠ÊèèËø∞„ÄÇ n=0Ë°®Á§∫ËæìÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÁªìÊùüÔºå‰∏çÂÅöÂ§ÑÁêÜ„ÄÇ ÂØπ‰∫éÊØè‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÔºåËæìÂá∫Âú®Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÊØçÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè„ÄÇÊØè‰∏™ËæìÂá∫Âç†‰∏ÄË°å„ÄÇ Input 2 4 5 0 Copy Output 2 4 6 Copy
È¢òËß£ Á¨¨nÂπ¥ÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè‰∏∫Ôºön-1Âπ¥ÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÂíå‰ªäÂπ¥Êñ∞Âá∫ÁîüÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè
‰ªäÂπ¥Êñ∞Âá∫ÁîüÁöÑÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè‰∏∫ n-3 Âπ¥ÂâçÁâõÁöÑÊï∞Èáè

#include <bits/stdc++.h> #include <iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; const int MOD = 1000; const int MAXN = 1000000; int val[MAXN] = {0}; void solve(int x) { if(val[x]!=0){ cout << val[x] << endl; return; } val[1]=1; val[2]=2; val[3]=3; for(int i=4;i<=x;i++){ val[i]=(val[i-1]+val[i-3]); } cout << val[x] << endl; } signed main() { int x; cin >> x; while (x) { solve(x); cin >> x; } return 0; } Copy



Ê•ºÊ¢ØÊúâÈò∂Âè∞Èò∂,‰∏äÊ•ºÊó∂ÂèØ‰ª•‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏äÈò∂,‰πüÂèØ‰ª•‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏äÈò∂,‰πüÂèØ‰ª•‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏äÈò∂
ÁºñÁ®ãËÆ°ÁÆóÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÁßç‰∏çÂêåÁöÑËµ∞Ê≥ï„ÄÇ

ËæìÂÖ•ÁöÑÊØè‰∏ÄË°åÂåÖÊã¨‰∏ÄÁªÑÊµãËØïÊï∞ÊçÆÔºåÂç≥‰∏∫Âè∞Èò∂Êï∞n„ÄÇÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄË°å‰∏∫0ÔºåË°®Á§∫ÊµãËØïÁªìÊùü„ÄÇ

ÊØè‰∏ÄË°åËæìÂá∫ÂØπÂ∫î‰∏ÄË°åËæìÂÖ•ÁöÑÁªìÊûúÔºåÂç≥‰∏∫Ëµ∞Ê≥ïÁöÑÊï∞ÁõÆ„ÄÇ

Input
1 2 3 4 0 Copy
Output
1 2 4 7 Copy

Success Ë°®Á§∫Ëµ∞Âà∞Á¨¨Á∫ßÂè∞Èò∂ÁöÑËµ∞Ê≥ï
WhyÔºü Ë¶Å‰∏äÁ¨¨Á∫ßÊ•ºÊ¢Ø
ÂèØ‰ª•‰ªéÁ∫ßÊ•ºÊ¢Ø‰∏ÄÊ¨°Ëµ∞‰∏ÄÊ≠•‰∏äÂéª
ÂèØ‰ª•‰ªéÁ∫ßÊ•ºÊ¢Ø‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊÄßËµ∞‰∏§Ê≠•‰∏äÂéª
ÂèØ‰ª•‰ªéÁ∫ßÊ•ºÊ¢Ø‰∏ÄÊ¨°ÊÄßËµ∞‰∏âÊ≠•‰∏äÂéª

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; int a[101]={0}; signed main() { a[1]=1; a[2]=2; a[3]=4; int n; cin >> n; while(n){ for(int i=4;i<=n;i++){ a[i]=a[i-1]+a[i-2]+a[i-3]; } cout << a[n] << endl; cin >> n; } return 0; } Copy


Âú®2√ónÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈïøÊñπÂΩ¢ÊñπÊ†º‰∏≠,Áî®‰∏Ä‰∏™1√ó2ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÈì∫Êª°ÊñπÊ†º,ËæìÂÖ•n ,ËæìÂá∫Èì∫ÊîæÊñπÊ°àÁöÑÊÄªÊï∞. ‰æãÂ¶Çn=3Êó∂,‰∏∫2√ó 3ÊñπÊ†ºÔºåÈ™®ÁâåÁöÑÈì∫ÊîæÊñπÊ°àÊúâ‰∏âÁßç,Â¶Ç‰∏ãÂõæÔºö

ËæìÂÖ•Êï∞ÊçÆÁî±Â§öË°åÁªÑÊàêÔºåÊØèË°åÂåÖÂê´‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞n,Ë°®Á§∫ËØ•ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÁöÑÈïøÊñπÂΩ¢ÊñπÊ†ºÁöÑËßÑÊ†ºÊòØ2√ón (0< n<=50)„ÄÇ

 ÂØπ‰∫éÊØè‰∏™ÊµãËØïÂÆû‰æãÔºåËØ∑ËæìÂá∫Èì∫ÊîæÊñπÊ°àÁöÑÊÄªÊï∞ÔºåÊØè‰∏™ÂÆû‰æãÁöÑËæìÂá∫Âç†‰∏ÄË°å„ÄÇ

Input
1 3 2 Copy
Output
1 3 2 Copy

‰∏∫‰∫Ü‰ΩøÊñπÊ†ºÈì∫Êª°ÔºåÊØèÊ¨°Ë¶Å‰πàÈì∫‰∏Ä‰∏™2√ó1ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÔºåË¶Å‰πàÈì∫‰∏§‰∏™1√ó2ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÔºåË¶Å‰πàÈì∫‰∏§‰∏™2√ó1ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÈ¶ñÂÖàÔºåÂàÜÊûêËæπÁïåÂÄºÔºö2√ó1ÊñπÊ†ºÂè™Êúâ1ÁßçÈì∫Ê≥ïÔºå2√ó2ÊñπÊ†ºÂè™Êúâ2ÁßçÈì∫Ê≥ï.Â¶ÇÂõæÔºö

]Ë°®Á§∫Èì∫Êª°ÁöÑÈïøÊñπÂΩ¢ÊñπÊ†ºÔºå‰∏ÄÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÊñπÊ°àÊï∞
Èì∫Âà∞ÊúÄÂêéË¶Å‰πàÂâ©ÊàñËÄÖ
Ë°®Á§∫Ââç Â∑≤Èì∫Êª°ÔºåÂâ©ÊúÄÂêéÂè™ËÉΩÁ´ñÁùÄÊîæ
‰∏∫Èì∫Êª° ÁΩëÊ†ºÁöÑÊñπÊ°àÊï∞
(Â¶ÇÊûúÂâçÈù¢ÁöÑ2*(n-2)ÁöÑÁΩëÊ†ºÂ∑≤ÁªèÈì∫Êª°, ÈÇ£‰πàÊúÄÂêéÁöÑÂè™ËÉΩÊòØÊ®™ÁùÄÊîæ‰∏§Âùó,Âê¶Âàô‰ºö‰∏éÈáçÂ§ç).

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; int a[51]={0}; signed main() { a[1]=1, a[2]=2; int n=0; while(cin>>n){ for(int i=3;i<=n;i++){ a[i]=a[i-1]+a[i-2]; } cout << a[n] << endl; } return 0; } Copy


Ê°ÇÊûóÂ±±Ê∞¥Áî≤Â§©‰∏ãÔºåÊºìÊ±üÊõ¥ÊòØÁæé‰∏çËÉúÊî∂„ÄÇ ÊºìÊ±ü‰∏äÁ´πÁ≠èÊï¥ÈΩêÊéíÂàóÔºåÂΩ¢Êàê‰∫ÜÁæé‰∏ΩÁöÑÈ£éÊôØÁ∫øÔºåÊ¥•Ê¥•„ÄÅËè≤Ëè≤ÂíåÁöÆÁöÆÂÜ≥ÂÆö‰πòÂùêÁ´πÁ≠èÊ∏∏ËßàÊºìÊ±üÊôØËâ≤„ÄÇ Â∑≤Áü•Á´πÁ≠èÊúâ2ÁßçËßÑÊ†ºÔºö‰∏ÄÁßçÊòØÂçï‰∫∫Á´πÁ≠èÔºåÈïøÂ∫¶‰∏∫1ÔºåÂÆΩÂ∫¶‰∏∫1ÔºõÂè¶‰∏ÄÁßçÊòØÂèå‰∫∫Á´πÁ≠èÔºåÈïøÂ∫¶‰∏∫ 2ÔºåÂÆΩÂ∫¶‰∏∫2„ÄÇÂÅáËÆæÊºìÊ±üÊ±üÈù¢ÁöÑÈù¢ÁßØÊòØn*3ÔºåËØ∑ÈóÆÂ§öÂ∞ëÁßç‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁ´πÁ≠èÂÆâÊéíÊñπÊ°àÔºü

‰∏ÄË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞n,0<n<1000.

‰∏ÄË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞Ôºå‰∏∫Èì∫ËÆæÊñπÊ°àÁöÑÊï∞ÈáèÊ®°12345ÁöÑÁªìÊûú„ÄÇ

Input
2 Copy
Output
3 Copy

$$f(n)=\begin{cases} \ 1 & n= 1\
\ 2 & n= 2\
d[i-1]+2\times d[i-2] \ &n>2
\end{cases}$d[i]$ Ë°®Á§∫ Ê±üÈù¢ÂÆΩÂ∫¶‰∏∫Êó∂Èì∫ËÆæÊñπÊ°àÁöÑÊï∞
Why ? ÂΩìÂÆΩÂ∫¶ÊòØ‰∫åÁöÑÊó∂ÂÄôÔºåÊúâ‰∏§ÁßçÊéíÂàóÊñπÊ≥ï

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n'; using namespace std; const int MOD=12345; int f(int n){ if(n==1) return 1; if(n==2) return 3; return f(n-1)+2*f(n-2); } signed main(){ int n; cin>>n; int d[n+1]; d[0]=0,d[1]=1,d[2]=3; for(int i=3;i<=n;i++){ d[i]=(d[i-1]+2*d[i-2])%MOD; } cout<<d[n]<<endl; return 0; } Copy


Ê°ÇÊûó‰∏∫‰∫ÜÊ¨¢ËøéÂπøÂ§ßÊ∏∏ÂÆ¢ÔºåÂÜ≥ÂÆöÂú®Ê°ÇÊûóÁöÑÂêÑÂ§ßË°óÈÅì‰∏äÂ∏ÉÁΩÆËøéÂÆæÂΩ©Â∏¶„ÄÇ ÁõÆÂâçÊúâÁôΩËâ≤„ÄÅËìùËâ≤ÂíåÁ∫¢Ëâ≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶ÔºåÂπ∂Êª°Ë∂≥‰ª•‰∏ã‰∏§‰∏™Êù°‰ª∂Ôºö

Áõ∏ÂêåÈ¢úËâ≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶‰∏çËÉΩÊîæÂú®Áõ∏ÈÇªÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆ
‰∏ÄÊù°ËìùËâ≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶ÂøÖÈ°ªÊîæÂú®‰∏ÄÊù°ÁôΩËâ≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶Âíå‰∏ÄÊù°Á∫¢Ëâ≤ÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶‰∏≠Èó¥„ÄÇ Ê¥•Ê¥•„ÄÅËè≤Ëè≤ÂíåÁöÆÁöÆÂÜ≥ÂÆöÂÜô‰∏Ä‰∏™Á®ãÂ∫èÔºå‰∫ÜËß£ÊîæÁΩÆÂΩ©Â∏¶ÁöÑÊñπÊ°àÊï∞ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÁßç„ÄÇ

‰∏ÄË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞nÔºåË°®Á§∫Ê©±Á™óÁöÑÂÆΩÂ∫¶ÔºàÊàñËÄÖËØ¥ÂΩ©Â∏¶Êï∞ÁõÆÔºâ„ÄÇ

‰∏ÄË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞ÔºåË°®Á§∫Ë£ÖÈ•∞Ê©±Á™óÁöÑÂΩ©Â∏¶ÊîæÁΩÆÊñπÊ°àÊï∞„ÄÇ

Input
3 Copy
Output
4 Copy

$$f(n)=\begin{cases} \ 2 & n= 1\
\ 2 & n= 2\
d(i-1)+d(i-2) \ &n>2
\end{cases}$d[i]$ Ë°®Á§∫ÂΩìÊ©±Á™óÂÆΩÂ∫¶ÊòØ Êó∂ÔºåÂΩ©Â∏¶ÊîæÁΩÆÊñπÊ°àÊï∞
Why ?
ÂÅáËÆæ‰∏ÄÂÖ±Êúâ Êù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶ÔºåÂΩìÂâç Êù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶ÊéíÂ•ΩÂêéÔºåÂàôÊúÄÂêé‰∏ÄÊù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶
‰∏ÄÂÆöÂè™ËÉΩÊòØÁ∫¢Ëâ≤ÊàñËÄÖÂè™ËÉΩÊòØÁôΩËâ≤
ÂØπ‰∫éÁ¨¨ Êù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶Â≠òÂú®‰∏§ÁßçÂèØËÉΩ
ËìùËâ≤ÊàñËÄÖ‰∏çÊòØËìùËâ≤
- ÂΩì‰∏∫ËìùËâ≤Êó∂Á¨¨ Êù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶‰πüÂøÖÁÑ∂ÊòØÁ°ÆÂÆöÁöÑ
- ‰∏ç‰∏∫ËìùËâ≤Êó∂Á¨¨ Êù°ÂΩ©Â∏¶‰∏çËÉΩÁ°ÆÂÆö


#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n'; using namespace std; signed main(){ int n; cin>>n; int a[n+1]={0}; a[1]=2,a[2]=2; for(int i=3;i<=n;i++){ a[i]=a[i-2]+a[i-1]; } cout<<a[n]<<endl; return 0; } Copy


Ê°ÇÊûóÁöÑÊôØÁÇπÂæàÂ§öÔºå‰∏∫‰∫ÜËÆ©Êõ¥Â§öÁöÑÊ∏∏ÂÆ¢ÂèØ‰ª•È°∫Âà©Ê∏∏Áé©„ÄÇÂú®‰∏çÂΩ±ÂìçÊ∏∏ËßàÂìÅË¥®ÁöÑÂâçÊèê‰∏ãÔºåÊóÖÊ∏∏ÂÖ¨Âè∏ ÂÜ≥ÂÆöÈÄöËøáÊîπÂèòË∑ØÁ∫øÁöÑÊñπÊ≥ïÂàÜÊµÅÊ∏∏ÂÆ¢„ÄÇ ÊñπÊ°àÊòØÔºöÊØè‰∏™ÊóÖË°åÂõ¢ÈÉΩË∑≥ËøáÂÖ∂‰∏≠ÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊôØÁÇπÔºà‰ΩÜÊòØ‰∏çËÉΩË∑≥ËøáÂè∑ÂíåÂè∑ÊôØÁÇπÔºâÔºå‰ΩøÂæóÂÆÉ‰ªéÂè∑ÊôØÁÇπÂºÄÂßãÔºåÂà∞ËææÂè∑ÊôØÁÇπÊâÄÁªèËøáÁöÑÊÄªË∑ùÁ¶ªÊúÄÂ∞è„ÄÇ ÂÅáËÆæÊØè‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊôØÁÇπiÈÉΩÊúâ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂùêÊ†áÔºå‰ªéÁöÑÊôØÁÇπÂà∞ ÁöÑÊôØÁÇπ ÁöÑË∑ùÁ¶ª‰∏∫Ôºö

Á¨¨1Ë°å1‰∏™Ê≠£Êï¥Êï∞nÔºåË°®Á§∫ÂüéÂ∏Ç‰∏™Êï∞„ÄÇ

‰∏ÄË°å‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï∞Ôºå‰ΩøÂæóÂÆÉ‰ªé1Âè∑ÂüéÂ∏ÇÂºÄÂßãÔºåË∑≥ËøáÊüê‰∏Ä‰∏™ÂüéÂ∏ÇÔºåÂà∞ËæænÂè∑ÂüéÂ∏ÇÊâÄÁªèËøáÁöÑÊúÄÂ∞èÊÄªË∑ùÁ¶ª„ÄÇ

ÂÖàËÆ°ÁÆóÂá∫ÊÄªË∑ùÁ¶ªS (ÊØè‰∏™ÊôØÁÇπ‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊõºÂìàÈ°øË∑ùÁ¶ªÊÄªÂíå)
ÈÄê‰∏™Ë∑≥ËøáÊôØÁÇπÁª¥Êä§ÊúÄÂ∞èË∑ùÁ¶ª
Success
ÂàùÂßãÂåñ‰∏∫
Ë°®Á§∫Ë∑≥ËøáÊôØÁÇπ ÁöÑÊÄªË∑ùÁ¶ª
Ë°®Á§∫‰∏çË∑≥Ëøá‰ªª‰Ωï‰∏Ä‰∏™ÊôØÁÇπÁöÑÊÄªË∑ùÁ¶ª
Ë°®Á§∫‰ªéÊôØÁÇπ Âà∞ ÊôØÁÇπ ÁöÑË∑ùÁ¶ª
Ë°®Á§∫ ‰∏§ÊôØÁÇπ‰πãÈó¥ÁöÑÊõºÂìàÈ°øË∑ùÁ¶ª

ÂÅáËÆæ A, B‰∏§ÁÇπÂùêÊ†áÂàÜÂà´‰∏∫ Ôºå
‰ªéÂà∞ÁöÑÊõºÂìàÈ°øË∑ùÁ¶ª‰∏∫:
int manhattandist(int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2){ return abs(x1 - x2) + abs(y1 - y2); } Copy

#include <bits/stdc++.h> #include <iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; int n, m, b, s, a[100005], x[100005], y[100005]; int manhattandist(int x1, int y1, int x2, int y2){ return abs(x1 - x2) + abs(y1 - y2); } int dist(int i, int j){ return manhattandist(x[i], y[i], x[j], y[j]); } signed main(){ cin >> n; for (int i = 1; i <= n; i++){ cin >> x[i] >> y[i]; if (i > 1) a[i] = dist(i, i - 1); s += a[i]; } m = s; for (int i = 2; i <= n - 1; i++){ b = s - a[i] - a[i + 1] + dist(i - 1, i + 1); m = min(m, b); } cout << m << endl; return 0; } Copy


Áå¥Â≠êÂêÉÊ°ÉÂ≠êÈóÆÈ¢òÔºöÁå¥Â≠êÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂ§©Êëò‰∏ãËã•Âπ≤‰∏™Ê°ÉÂ≠êÔºåÂΩìÂç≥ÂêÉ‰∫Ü‰∏ÄÂçäËøò‰∏çËøáÁòæÔºåÂèàÂ§öÂêÉ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™ÔºõÁ¨¨‰∫åÂ§©ÂèàÂ∞ÜÂâ©‰∏ãÁöÑÊ°ÉÂ≠êÂêÉÊéâ‰∏ÄÂçäÂèàÂ§öÂêÉ‰∫Ü‰∏Ä‰∏™Ôºõ‰ª•ÂêéÊØèÂ§©Êó©‰∏äÈÉΩÂêÉ‰∫ÜÂâç‰∏ÄÂ§©Ââ©‰∏ãÁöÑ‰∏ÄÂçäÈõ∂‰∏Ä‰∏™„ÄÇÂà∞‰∫ÜÁ¨¨ÂçÅÂ§©ÊÉ≥ÂÜçÂêÉÊó∂ÔºåËßÅÂè™Ââ©‰∏ã‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê°ÉÂ≠êÔºåÊ±ÇÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂ§©ÂÖ±Êëò‰∫ÜÂ§öÂ∞ë‰∏™Ê°ÉÂ≠êÔºü

Êó†

‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞ÔºåÁ¨¨‰∏ÄÂ§©ÂÖ±ÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ë‰∏™Ê°ÉÂ≠ê

#include <iostream> using namespace std; int peaches_2(int day) { if (day == 10) { return 1; } else { return (peaches_2(day + 1) + 1) * 2; } } int peaches_1(int day) { int total_peaches = 1; for (int i = 10; i > 1 ; --i) { total_peaches = (total_peaches + 1) * 2; } return total_peaches; } int main() { int day = 1; int total_peaches = peaches_1(day); cout << total_peaches << endl; return 0; } Copy


Êúâ1√ónÔºàn<=50ÔºâÁöÑ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈïøÊñπÂΩ¢ÔºåÁî®1√ó1„ÄÅ1√ó2Âíå1√ó3ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÈì∫Êª°ÊñπÊ†ºÔºåËØ∑ÈóÆÊúâÂ§öÂ∞ëÁßçÈì∫Ê≥ïÔºü ‰æãÂ¶ÇÂΩìn=3Êó∂‰∏∫1√ó3ÁöÑÊñπÊ†º„ÄÇÊ≠§Êó∂Áî®1√ó1„ÄÅ1√ó2Âíå1√ó3ÁöÑÈ™®ÁâåÈì∫Êª°ÊñπÊ†ºÔºåÂÖ±ÊúâÂõõÁßçÈì∫Ê≥ï„ÄÇÂ¶Ç‰∏ãÂõæÔºö

‰∏Ä‰∏™Êï¥Êï∞nÔºàn<=50Ôºâ

È™®ÁâåÁöÑÈì∫Ê≥ï

OutPut

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; signed main(){ int n=0; cin>>n; int dp[52]; dp[0]=0; dp[1]=1; dp[2]=2; dp[3]=4; for(int i=4;i<=n;i++){ dp[i]=dp[i-1]+dp[i-2]+dp[i-3]; } cout<<dp[n]<<endl; return 0; } Copy


PellÊï∞ÂàóÁöÑÂÆö‰πâÊòØËøôÊ†∑ÁöÑÔºåÔºå„ÄÇ ÁªôÂá∫‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê≠£Êï¥Êï∞kÔºåË¶ÅÊ±ÇPellÊï∞ÂàóÁöÑÁ¨¨È°πÊ®°‰∏äÊòØÂ§öÂ∞ë„ÄÇ

Á¨¨1Ë°åÊòØÊµãËØïÊï∞ÊçÆÁöÑÁªÑÊï∞nÔºåÂêéÈù¢Ë∑üÁùÄnË°åËæìÂÖ•„ÄÇÊØèÁªÑÊµãËØïÊï∞ÊçÆÂç†1Ë°åÔºåÂåÖÊã¨‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê≠£Êï¥Êï∞k (1 ‚â§ k < 1000000)„ÄÇ

nË°åÔºåÊØèË°åËæìÂá∫ÂØπÂ∫î‰∏Ä‰∏™ËæìÂÖ•„ÄÇËæìÂá∫Â∫îÊòØ‰∏Ä‰∏™ÈùûË¥üÊï¥Êï∞„ÄÇ

Input

#include<bits/stdc++.h> #include<iostream> #define int long long #define endl '\n' using namespace std; int a[1000001]={0}; void solve(int n){ a[1]=1; a[2]=2; for(int i=3;i<=n;i++){ a[i]=(2*a[i-1]+a[i-2])%32767; } } signed main() { int T=0; cin>>T; while(T--){ int n=0; cin>>n; if(a[n]!=0) cout<<a[n]<<endl; else{ solve(n); cout<<a[n]<<endl; } } return 0; } Copy

item.description:
ÊúÄÈïøÂõûÊñáÂ≠ê‰∏≤ ÁªôÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ sÔºåÊâæÂà∞ s ‰∏≠ÊúÄÈïøÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂ≠ê‰∏≤„ÄÇ Á§∫‰æã 1Ôºö ËæìÂÖ•Ôºös = "babad"
ËæìÂá∫Ôºö"bab"
Ëß£ÈáäÔºö"aba" ÂêåÊ†∑ÊòØÁ¨¶ÂêàÈ¢òÊÑèÁöÑÁ≠îÊ°à„ÄÇ Á§∫‰æã 2Ôºö ËæìÂÖ•Ôºös = "cbbd"
ËæìÂá∫Ôºö"bb" ÊèêÁ§∫Ôºö
1 <= s.length <= 1000
s ‰ªÖÁî±Êï∞Â≠óÂíåËã±ÊñáÂ≠óÊØçÁªÑÊàê


ÂØπÊØè‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÈÉΩÂêë‰∏§‰æßÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÂà§Êñ≠ÊòØÂê¶‰∏∫ÂõûÊñá‰∏≤
ÂÅ∂Êï∞ÂõûÊñá‰∏≤Êó†Ê≥ïÁõ¥Êé•‰∏≠ÂøÉÊâ©Â±ï



Âú®ÊØè‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÂâçÂêéÊèíÂÖ•‰∏Ä‰∏™Êâ©Â±ïÂ≠óÁ¨¶Ôºå‰ΩøÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÈïøÂ∫¶‰∏ÄÂÆö‰∏∫Â•áÊï∞
ÂèØ‰ª•Êñπ‰æøÁöÑÂØªÊâæÂ•áÈïøÂ∫¶„ÄÅÂÅ∂ÈïøÂ∫¶ÁöÑÂõûÊñáÔºåÊâ©Â±ïÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÂèØ‰ª•ÈöèÊÑèËÆæÁΩÆÔºå‰∏ç‰ºöÂΩ±ÂìçËÆ°ÁÆó


ÂõûÊñáË¶ÜÁõñÊúÄÂè≥ËæπÁïår„ÄÅÂõûÊñá‰∏≠ÂøÉc


Âú®‰∏Ä‰∏™Â§ßÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂå∫ÂüüÂÜÖÔºåÊó†ÈúÄÂØπÂõûÊñá‰∏≠ÂøÉ‰πãÂêéÁöÑÊØè‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶Êö¥ÂäõÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÂ∞±ÂèØ‰ª•ÂæóÂà∞ËØ•Â≠óÁ¨¶ÁöÑÊúÄÂ§ßÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ

ÂÅáËÆæ‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ sÔºå Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤sÁöÑ ManacherÊâ©Â±ï‰∏≤‰∏∫ pÔºåp[i] Ë°®Á§∫ÂΩìÂâçÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÂèØ‰ª•Êâ©Â±ïÁöÑÊúÄÈïøÂõûÊñá‰∏≤ÁöÑÈïøÂ∫¶

Áé∞Âú®ÂÅáËÆæÊàë‰ª¨Ë¶ÅÂØπ‰∏ã‰∏Ä‰∏™  ËÆ°ÁÆó  ÔºåÊ≠§Êó∂‰πãÂâçÊâÄÊúâÁöÑÂÄºÂ∑≤ËÆ°ÁÆóÂÆåÊØï„ÄÇÊàë‰ª¨Â∞ÜÈÄöËøá‰∏ãÂàóÊñπÂºèËÆ°ÁÆóÔºö

Â¶ÇÊûú ‰Ωç‰∫éÂΩìÂâçÂ≠êÂõûÊñá‰∏≤‰πãÂ§ñÔºåÂç≥ÔºåÈÇ£‰πà‰ΩøÁî®Êö¥ÂäõËß£Ê≥ï
‰ª•i‰∏∫‰∏≠ÂøÉÊÉ≥‰∏§‰æßÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÊ£ÄÈ™åÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÊòØÂê¶Áõ∏ÂêåÔºåÁõ¥Âà∞‰∏çÂêå
Â¶ÇÊûú Ôºå ÂàôÂ∞ùËØïÈÄöËøáÂ∑≤ÁªèËÆ°ÁÆóÂá∫ÁöÑ, Âä†ÈÄüÂΩìÂâçÁöÑËÆ°ÁÆó
È¶ñÂÖàËÆ°ÁÆóÂá∫ÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπÁöÑ‰∏ãÊ†á
ÂΩìÂâç‰∏ãÊ†á‰∏éÂÖ∂ÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπÔºàÂÅáËÆæ‰∏∫ ÔºâÂÖ≥‰∫éÂΩìÂâçÂõûÊñá‰∏≠ÂøÉ ÂØπÁß∞
Âç≥

ÔºåÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπ ÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ()ÔºåÂú®Â§ßÂõûÊñáÂå∫Âüü‰ª•ÂÜÖÔºåÁõ¥Êé•Á°ÆÂÆö

Âõ†‰∏∫ÂÖ∂ÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπÂ∑≤ÁªèÊó†Ê≥ïÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÖ∂Êú¨Ë∫´‰πüÊó†Ê≥ïÊâ©Â±ï

ÔºåÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπ 2*c-i ÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ s[2*c-i]ÔºåÂú®Â§ßÂõûÊñáÂå∫Âüü‰ª•Â§ñÔºåÁõ¥Êé•Á°ÆÂÆöÔºåÂΩìÂâçÂ§ßÂõûÊñáÂå∫ÂüüÂçäÂæÑ-ÂΩìÂâç‰∏ãÊ†á

Âõ†‰∏∫Â§ßÂõûÊñá‰∏≤Â∑≤ÁªèÊó†Ê≥ïÊâ©Â±ïÔºåÊâÄ‰ª•ÂÖ∂Êú¨Ë∫´‰πüÊó†Ê≥ïÊâ©Â±ï

ÔºåÂØπÁß∞ÁÇπ ÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ()ÔºåÂàöÂ•ΩÂú®Â§ßÂõûÊñáÂå∫ÂüüÁöÑËæπÁïå

‰ªér‰πãÂ§ñÁöÑ‰ΩçÁΩÆËøõË°åÊâ©Â±ï

ÂΩìÂâçÂ≠óÁ¨¶ÊúÄÈïøÂõûÊñá‰∏≤ÁöÑÂÆûÈôÖÈïøÂ∫¶

ÊØè‰∏™Â≠êÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤Êâ©Â±ïÂêéÁöÑÈïøÂ∫¶‰∏∫
ÊØè‰∏™Â≠êÂõûÊñáÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤Êâ©Â±ïÂêéÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ‰∏∫


ÂÆûÈôÖÂõûÊñá‰∏≤ÁªàÊ≠¢‰ΩçÁΩÆ = Êâ©Â±ïÂõûÊñá‰∏≤ÁªìÂ∞æ‰∏ãÊ†á / 2




string Preprocess(string s) { // Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤È¢ÑÂ§ÑÁêÜ string res = "#"; //Âú®ÊØè‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶ÂâçÂêéÊ∑ªÂä†Êâ©Â±ïÂ≠óÁ¨¶ for (int i = 0; i < s.size(); i++) { res += s[i]; res += "#"; } return res; } string Manacher(string s) { string t = Preprocess(s); string ans = ""; vector<int> p(t.size(), 0); int mx = 0; for(int i = 0, c = 0, r = 0, len; i < t.size(); i++) { // ÂΩì i < r Êó∂, // Ëã•Ê≠§Êó∂ i + s[i] Âú® r ÂÜÖÔºå Âàô r - i >= p[2 * c - i] // len = p[2 * c - i] // Ëã•Ê≠§Êó∂ i + s[i] Âú® r Â§ñÔºå Âàô r - i <= p[2 * c - i] // len = r - i // ÂΩì i >= r Êó∂ // ÂõûÊñáÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤Âç≥‰∏∫ i Êú¨Ë∫´Ôºålen = 1 len = i < r ? min(r - i, p[2 * c - i]) : 1; while (i + len < t.size() && i - len >= 0 && t[i + len] == t[i - len]){ // ‰∏çÁÆ°ÊòØÂê¶ÂèØ‰ª•Êâ©Â±ïÔºåÈÉΩÂ∞ùËØïÊâ©Â±ï len++; } if (i + len > r){ //Êõ¥Êñ∞Êñ∞ÁöÑÂõûÊñá‰∏≠ÂøÉÂíåÂõûÊñáÂçäÂæÑ r = i + len; c = i; } if(len > mx){ // Áª¥Êä§ÊúÄÈïøÂõûÊñáÂ≠êÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ mx = len; ans = s.substr((i - len + 1)/2, len - 1); } p[i] = len; } return ans; } Copy


ÂõûÊñáÂ≠ê‰∏≤ ËøîÂõûÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤sÁöÑÂõûÊñáÂ≠ê‰∏≤Êï∞Èáè

‰∏çÈáçÂè†ÂõûÊñáÂ≠êÂ≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤ÁöÑÊúÄÂ§ßÊï∞ÁõÆ ÁªôÂÆö‰∏Ä‰∏™Â≠óÁ¨¶‰∏≤strÂíå‰∏Ä‰∏™Ê≠£Êï∞k

item.title: DCN-Assignment1DCN-Assignment1
item.description:
What is the OSI model?

There are 7 layers in the in OSI Model

Physical Layer
It is concerned with transmitting raw bits over a communication channel.
Data Link Layer
It is to transform a raw transmission facility into a line that appears free of undetected transmission errors to the network layer.
Network Layer
It controls the operation of the subnet.
Transport Layer
It is to accept data from above, split it up into smaller units if need be, pass these to the network layer, and ensure that the pieces all arrive correctly at the other hand.
Session Layer
It allows users on different machines to establish sessions between them.
Presentation Layer
It is concerned with the syntax and semantics of the information transmitted.
Application Layer
It contains a variety of protocols that are commonly needed by users, such as HTTP, Email, etc.

There are no Session Layer and Presentation Layer in TCP/IP models

A company‚Äôs computer network is the backbone of its business as it connects all its computers and related devices, allowing staff to work more efficiently across the organization. Suppose a commercial company has about 8000 staff. As a computer officer in the company, you are required to design a computer network for that company. Note that network design involves evaluating and understanding how all the elements of the network link together and how they can be made to run as efficiently as possible. Please answer the following questions.


Star topology will be used in this network


Central Connection Point (Hub, Switch, or Router)
Nodes (Computers, Printers, Servers, etc.)
Cabling


Cost: This includes the initial setup expenses as well as ongoing maintenance and operation costs. Effective design balances affordability with performance and scalability requirements.
Stability: A stable network ensures consistent availability and reliability, minimizing downtime and supporting productivity. This involves choosing dependable hardware and implementing redundancy where necessary.
Scalability: The network should be able to grow and adapt to increased demands without extensive redesigns. This means planning for future expansions in users, devices, and data volumes.
Performance: Network performance affects data transmission speed and efficiency. A well-designed network minimizes latency and maximizes throughput to provide a smooth user experience.
Complexity: While some complexity might be necessary for functionality, a simpler network is generally easier to manage and troubleshoot. The goal is to find the optimal balance that meets the network's objectives without unnecessary complication.



The CRC method is used to transmit a bit-stream of with the generator polynomial .


Frame:
Message after 3 zero bits are appended:
Reminder:

Show that this error is detected at the receiver‚Äôs end.

Receive Frame:
Receive Data:
Calculate Reminder:

it can detect the error






the Hamming code for the bit-stream is
1010 1010 1010 1010 0

Error correction, and error-detection, and retransmission can be used to tackle error bits in data communication. State two reasons why some applications use error correction instead of error detection and retransmission.

For some application that need Real-time or Low latency, Delays in processes such as waiting for retransmissions can degrade the quality of service and the user experience.
In environments where communication channels are inherently noisy or prone to high error rates (e.g., deep space communications, underwater communications), it may not be practical or efficient to retransmit data every time an error is detected.

The Internet of Things (IoT) is doing great in many fields and services. Numerous IoT applications can ease our commercial operations. Suppose you are a project leader in a software house, and your team is required to write a proposal about IoT innovation. Please suggest what kind of application you would propose and why.
Proposal:

A Smart Waste Management System. This system would leverage IoT technology to optimize waste collection and processing in urban areas.
Why:

A Smart Waste Management System utilizing IoT technology offers a holistic solution to urban waste challenges by enhancing environmental sustainability, reducing operational costs through optimized routes and schedules.

item.description:
Protocol
Sender
Message
Medium
Receiver


Simplex
Half-duplex
Full-duplex



Assumption: noise free in the channel
Formula:
B = Bit Rate (bit/sec)
F = Channel Bandwidth in Hertz
M = Number of levels in a signal (two for binary)


In reality, the signal may be corrupted by electrical noise.
Formula:
B = Actual Bit Rate (bit/sec)
F = Channel Bandwidth in Hertz
S = Signal Power in watts
N = Noise Power in watts


The signal-to-noise ratio is often given in decibels.


Assume that = 36 and the channel bandwidth is 2 MHz.




Physical Layer:
It is concerned with transmitting raw bits over a communication channel.
This layer deals with the issues including mechanical, electrical, timing interfaces, and the physical transmission medium.
Data Link Layer:
It is to transform a raw transmission facility into a line that appears free of undetected transmission errors to the network layer.
Network Layer:
It controls the operation of the subnet.
It routes packets from source to destination.
The routing algorithm can be static or dynamic.
Transport Layer:
It is to accept data from upper layers.
Split it up into smaller units if need be, pass these to the network layer,
Ensure that the pieces all arrive correctly at the other hand.
Session Layer:
It allows users on different machines to establish sessions between them.
Presentation Layer:
It is concerned with the syntax and semantics of the information transmitted.
Application Layer:
It contains a variety of protocols that are commonly needed by users.
Such as HTTP, Email, etc.

Physical Layer:

It is concerned with transmitting raw bits over a communication channel.
This layer deals with the issues including mechanical, electrical, timing interfaces, and the physical transmission medium.

Guided media, which are those that provide a conduit from one device to another.

Guide wired
Twisted-pair cable
Coaxial cable
Fiber-optic


Mode
Multimode
Step index
Graded index
Single mode

Unguided media transport electromagnetic waves without using a physical conductor.

Unguided wireless
Free space
Two common signal encoding methods:

Frequency hopping spread spectrum (e.g., Bluetooth)
Direct sequence spread spectrum (e.g.,CDMA mobile network)
The Electromagnetic Spectrum

Propagation Methods
Ground Propagation
Sky Propagation
Line-of-sight Propagation

Data Link Layer:

It is to transform a raw transmission facility into a line that appears free of undetected transmission errors to the network layer.


Character Count
Flag bytes with byte stuffing
Starting and ending flags with bit stuffing



Parity Check
Two-dimensional Parity Check
Cyclic Redundancy Check (CRC)



Hamming Distance
Hamming Code


Error detection:
To send additional information, so incorrect data can be detected and rejected.
Error correction:
To send additional information, so incorrect data can be corrected and accepted.
Error correction is the additional ability to reconstruct the original data.


Stop-and-Wait Protocols
Sliding Window Protocols


Channelization:
Frequency-Division Multiple Access (FDMA)
Time-Division Multiple Access (TDMA)
Code-Division Multiple Access (CDMA)
Random Access Protocols:
Aloha
Carrier Sense Multiple Access
CSMA with Collision Detection
CSMA with Collision Avoidance
Controlled-Access Protocols: Collision-Free Protocol
Reservation
Polling
Token passing

Network Layer:

It controls the operation of the subnet.
It routes packets from source to destination.
The routing algorithm can be static or dynamic.


IP is a protocol which governs the data format of packets sent over the Internet.
The main functions provided by IP are addressing and network routing.




Version
Type of service
Total length
Time to live
Source address, destination address


Version
Traffic class
Flow label
Payload length
Next header
Hop limit



Dual stack
Tunneling
Header translation

Network routing selects a path over an internetwork to transmit one or more packets from the source to the destination.





Transport Control Protocol (TCP)

Source port and destination port: to identify the local end points of the connections.
Sequence number and acknowledgement number
TCP header length: to tell how many 32-bit words are contained in the header
Six 1-bit flags
Window size: to tell how many bytes may be sent starting at the byte acknowledged.
Checksum
Options: to provide a way to extend the header

User Datagram Protocol (UDP)

Connectionless protocol
Provide a way for applications to send encapsulated IP datagrams and send them without having to establish a connection.
8-byte header
UDP Datagram Header



API stands for application programming interface.
Socket API is specifically designed for the network programming interface.

Socket is an abstraction through which an application may send and receive data.

A socket is uniquely identified together by
Internet address
End-to-end protocol (e.g. TCP or UDP)
Port number


Stream socket is designed for TCP, which provides reliable byte stream service.
Datagram socket is specifically designed for UDP, which provides best-effort datagram service.



WSAStartup

(send, recv) (recusive)
closesocket
WSACleanup


WSAStartup
socket
bind

(recv, send) (recursive)
closesocket (pair up with accept)
WASCleanup.


int socket_desc=socket(AF_INET,SOCK_STREAM,0); if (socket_desc==-1) perror("Create socket"); Copy

struct sockaddr_in address; /* type of socket created in socket() */ address.sin_family = AF_INET; address.sin_addr.s_addr = INADDR_ANY; /* 7000 is the port to use for connections */ address.sin_port = htons(7000); /* bind the socket to the port specified above */ bind(socket_desc,(struct sockaddr *)&address,sizeof(address)); Copy

listen(socket_desc,3); Copy

int addrlen; struct sockaddr_in address; addrlen = sizeof(struct sockaddr_in); new_socket = accept(socket_desc, (struct sockaddr *)&address, &addrlen); if (new_socket<0) perror("Accept connection"); Copy

char *message="This is a message to send\n\r"; send(socket_desc, message, strlen(message), 0); Copy

int bufsize=1024; /* a 1K buffer */ char *buffer=malloc(bufsize); recv(socket_desc,buffer,bufsize,0); Copy

closesocket(msg_sock); // close(socket_desc); WSACleanup(); Copy

#include <process.h> for(int i = 0; i < 100; i++){ _beginthread(accept_conn, 0, NULL ); }//for loop _endthread(); // create a function to accept a connection void accept_conn(void *dummy) { // doing something here } Copy

Bridge: bridge operates on Ethernet frames and thus a layer-2 device. It does the following two functions:

Filtering: determine whether a frame should be forwarded to some interface or should just be dropped.
Forwarding: determine the interfaces to which a frame should be directed.
Work on Data Link LayerData Link Layer

ÂÆö‰πâÔºöBridgeÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁΩëÁªúËÆæÂ§áÔºåÁî®‰∫éËøûÊé•‰∏§‰∏™ÊàñÂ§ö‰∏™ÁΩëÁªúÊÆµÔºå‰∏ªË¶ÅÁî®‰∫éÂàÜÂâ≤ÁΩëÁªúÂÜ≤Á™ÅÂüü„ÄÇ
Â∑•‰ΩúÂ±ÇÊ¨°ÔºöÊï∞ÊçÆÈìæË∑ØÂ±ÇÔºàOSIÊ®°ÂûãÁ¨¨2Â±ÇÔºâ„ÄÇ
Â∑•‰ΩúÂéüÁêÜÔºöBridgeÊ†πÊçÆMACÂú∞ÂùÄË°®ËΩ¨ÂèëÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∏ßÔºåÂè™Â∞ÜÊï∞ÊçÆÂ∏ßÂèëÈÄÅÂà∞ÁõÆÁöÑÂú∞ÊâÄÂú®ÁöÑÁΩëÁªúÊÆµÔºåÂáèÂ∞ë‰∏çÂøÖË¶ÅÁöÑÊµÅÈáè„ÄÇ
‰ºòÁÇπÔºöÂáèÂ∞ëÁΩëÁªúÂÜ≤Á™ÅÔºåÊèêÂçáÁΩëÁªúÊïàÁéá„ÄÇ
Áº∫ÁÇπÔºöÁÆ°ÁêÜÂ§çÊùÇÂ∫¶È´òÔºå‰∏çÊîØÊåÅÂ§öÊí≠ÂíåÂπøÊí≠ÊéßÂà∂„ÄÇ


Router: router is a store-and-forward packet switch that forward packets using network-layer addresses (layer-3).
Although a bridge is also a store- and-forward packet switch, it forwards packets using LAN addresses.
As a network administrator, how to choose between bridge and router?
Work on Network LayerNetwork Layer

ÂÆö‰πâÔºöRouterÊòØ‰∏ÄÁßçÁΩëÁªúËÆæÂ§áÔºåÁî®‰∫éËøûÊé•‰∏çÂêåÁöÑÁΩëÁªúÔºåËÉΩÂ§üÊ†πÊçÆIPÂú∞ÂùÄËøõË°åÊï∞ÊçÆÂåÖËΩ¨Âèë„ÄÇ
Â∑•‰ΩúÂ±ÇÊ¨°ÔºöÁΩëÁªúÂ±ÇÔºàOSIÊ®°ÂûãÁ¨¨3Â±ÇÔºâ„ÄÇ
Â∑•‰ΩúÂéüÁêÜÔºöRouterÊ†πÊçÆË∑ØÁî±Ë°®ÂíåIPÂú∞ÂùÄÈÄâÊã©ÊúÄ‰Ω≥Ë∑ØÂæÑÔºåÂ∞ÜÊï∞ÊçÆÂåÖËΩ¨ÂèëÂà∞ÁõÆÁöÑÂú∞ÁΩëÁªú„ÄÇ
‰ºòÁÇπÔºöËÉΩÂ§üËøûÊé•‰∏çÂêåÁ±ªÂûãÁöÑÁΩëÁªúÔºåÊîØÊåÅÂ§çÊùÇÁöÑË∑ØÁî±ÈÄâÊã©ÂçèËÆÆÔºåÊèê‰æõÂπøÂüüÁΩëÔºàWANÔºâËøûÊé•„ÄÇ
Áº∫ÁÇπÔºöÊàêÊú¨ËæÉÈ´òÔºåÈÖçÁΩÆÂíåÁÆ°ÁêÜÁõ∏ÂØπÂ§çÊùÇ„ÄÇ


Switch: switch is in essence a high-performance multi-interface bridge. The difference between a bridge and switch:
Bridges usually two or four interfaces, whereas switches have dozens of interfaces (e.g., 24 ports).
Switches are usually used to connect individual computers, and operate in a full-duplex mode.

.ORIG x3000 AND R2,R2,#0 LD R1,DIVIDND NOT R1,R1 ADD R1,R1,#1 LD R3,DIVISOR LOOP ADD R3,R3,R1 BRn DONE ADD R2,R2,#1 BRnzp LOOP DONE LD R4,DIVIDND ADD R3,R4,R3 LEA R0, Info PUTS HALT DIVISOR .FILL #30 DIVIDND .FILL #100 Info .STRINGZ "Example: R1 = 30, R6 = 100. Therefore 100/30, R2 = 3 and R3 = 10." .END Copy

Answer:

Interrupts: Using interrupts for handling I/O provides the advantage of allowing the processor to perform other tasks while waiting for I/O operations to complete. When an I/O device has finished its operation, it triggers an interrupt, allowing the CPU to immediately handle the data transfer or task associated with the I/O device. This approach is more efficient as it doesn't waste CPU cycles continuously checking the status of the I/O device.
Polling: Polling involves the CPU constantly checking the status of an I/O device to determine if it needs attention or has completed its task. It's simpler to implement but can be less efficient than using interrupts because it ties up the CPU in a loop, consuming processing power even when the I/O device doesn't need immediate attention. Polling might be used in scenarios where the hardware doesn't support interrupts or when the overhead of handling interrupts is too high compared to the frequency of I/O operations.

Answer:
The last instruction in the interrupt service program is usually "RTI" (opcode 1000). It returns from the Interrupt Pops PSR and PC of the Supervisor stack, recovering the conditional code from the PSR. If necessary (i.e., if the current permission mode is User), revert from Saved.USP to a user stack pointer to R6.

item.title: Problem
item.description:
Select any ISA instruction you have learned in the class, and analyze the process of the fetch-decode-execution cycle step by step. It should contain change of the state and change of the registers values, and PC, IR, MAR and MDR.


Fetch:
Load the address stored in the Program Counter (PC) into the Memory Address Register (MAR).
Send a "read" signal from MAR to memory to fetch the instruction.
Store the fetched instruction into the Instruction Register (IR).
Increment the Program Counter (PC) to point to the next instruction.
Decode:
Extract the opcode from the Instruction Register (IR).
Decode the opcode to recognize the instruction as an ADD operation.
Execute:
Fetch the source operands (Src1 and Src2) from the registers specified by the instruction's fields.
The Arithmetic Logic Unit (ALU) receives Src1 and Src2 values from the registers.
ALU performs the addition operation: ALU_result = Src1 + Src2.
Store the result (ALU_result) in the designated destination register (Dst).
